module.description: This PrepTest contains three scored LSAT sections  plus an additional section to simulate the unscored section in a real LSAT administration. Practice as if taking an actual test by following the test-taking instructions and timing yourself.

sections.directions: Directions: Each question in this section is based on the reasoning presented in a brief passage. In answering the questions, you should not make assumptions that are by commonsense standards implausible, superfluous, or incompatible with the passage. For some questions, more than one of the choices could conceivably answer the question. However, you are to choose the best answer; that is, choose the response that most accurately and completely answers the question.

items.stimulusText: Several years ago, most of one country's large banks failed and were taken over by a government agency. The agency is now selling these banks, aiming to strengthen the banking system in the process. But the banking system will not be strengthened if the former owners of these banks buy them back. So the agency is unlikely to achieve its goal, since _______.
items.stemText: The conclusion of the argument is properly drawn if which one of the following completes the passage?

options.optionContent: the agency may be unable to sell some of the banks
a single company could buy more than one of the banks
the country's overall economy is not much stronger than it was when the large banks failed
the banks sold by the agency will be financially weaker than the country's other banks for some time
all of the bidders for the banks are their former owners

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This choice doesn’t connect the given support and conclusion. The agency could be unable to sell a few banks but still succeed overall.
This choice doesn't follow from the support. Nothing presented in the argument suggests that one company owning multiple banks would be a problem.
This doesn’t support the conclusion that the agency is unlikely to achieve its goal.
The conclusion has to do with whether the agency will achieve its goal of strengthening the system. It is not about whether the banks succeed or fail.

This choice implies that the banks will be bought by their former owners, which connects the argument’s support (buy-backs would keep the agency from improving the banking system) to its conclusion (the agency is unlikely to succeed).

items.stimulusText: Accountant: The newspaper industry habitually cites the rising cost of newsprint to explain falling profits. But when corrected for inflation, the cost of newsprint is no more than it was ten years ago. Far from being victims of high costs, newspapers have been benefiting from cheap newsprint for decades. The real threats to their profitability are falling circulation and falling advertising.
items.stemText: The accountant's argument proceeds by

options.optionContent: reinterpreting a popular analogy in order to use that analogy to support an alternative conclusion
using economic data to raise doubts about the current effectiveness of a historically accepted approach
criticizing a newly developed method by demonstrating that a conventional method shows better results
challenging an explanation that has been given for a phenomenon in order to introduce a different explanation
calling into question a justification for a practice by showing how the same justification can be used to support a clearly undesirable practice

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The accountant doesn’t discuss analogies.
The accountant criticizes an explanation, not an **approach.** There is some discussion of economic data (the flat cost of newsprint), but it isn’t used to question the effectiveness of an approach.
The accountant does not criticize a **method**; the criticism is directed at a common explanation.
The accountant challenges the traditional “newsprint” explanation for falling profits and offers an alternative explanation.
The accountant does not discuss the **justification** for any **practice,** but instead offers an alternative explanation for a situation.

items.stimulusText: Peter: Recent evidence suggests that moderate alcohol consumption has certain beneficial effects on health. In particular, alcohol creates an inhospitable environment in the human body for certain bacteria that can cause illness. Thus, alcohol consumption is, on balance, beneficial.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately expresses a flaw in the reasoning in Peter's argument?

options.optionContent: It takes for granted that people choose to consume alcohol because they believe it is beneficial to their health.
It draws a comparison based on popular belief rather than on scientific opinion.
It fails to consider methods of achieving the same beneficial effects that do not involve alcohol.
It draws a conclusion about alcohol consumption in general from a premise about moderate alcohol consumption.
It fails to consider that alcohol may have no effect on many bacteria that cause illness in human beings.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This choice doesn't express a flaw in Peter's argument. His argument does not discuss **why** people do or don’t drink alcohol.
Peter’s argument does not make a comparison or discuss popular beliefs. Rather, it reaches a general conclusion based on narrow support.

This choice falls outside the scope of Peter's argument. The flaw in Peter's argument is that it uses narrow support to reach a general conclusion. The consideration of other ways to achieve benefits is not related to the support or conclusion.

This is the flaw in Peter's argument. The support tells us that moderate alcohol consumption has health benefits, but the conclusion is about alcohol consumption in general. For all we know, heavy drinking could be very unhealthy, which would contradict the conclusion.

[Note that "on balance" means "all things considered".]

This choice isn't the flaw. The flaw of Peter’s argument is that it generalizes a conclusion from narrow support.  He concludes that, overall, alcohol is beneficial, and it wouldn’t contradict this conclusion if alcohol had **no** effect on “many” harmful bacteria, as long as the benefits that it does provide are significant.

items.stimulusText: Consultant: Children taught using innovative new educational methods learn to think more creatively than children taught using rote methods such as drills, but they are less adept at memorizing large amounts of information. Most jobs at Grodex Corporation require the ability to think creatively but do not require a strong ability to memorize. So Grodex should probably conduct its employee-training seminars using the innovative methods, because _______.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most logically completes the consultant's argument?

options.optionContent: most of the employees at Grodex began in high school to learn the creative thinking skills that they later used on the job
corporations that conduct training seminars for employees using innovative educational methods are generally more successful than are corporations that do not conduct training seminars
less than half of the employees at Grodex regularly attend the company's training seminars
the effects of teaching methods in the education of adults are generally very similar to the effects of those methods in the education of children
knowing how to think creatively helps people to compensate for deficiencies in memorization skills

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This choice doesn’t help the argument. If most people have already gained creative thinking skills in high school, there is less reason to think Grodex needs to train employees to be creative.

This choice seems to give another reason for Grodex to use the innovative methods, but it is very general. The methods might help corporations overall, but will they help Grodex? Moreover, it compares corporations with seminars taught with the innovative methods to corporations with no seminars at all, whereas the argument compares different two different teaching methods.
This doesn’t help to connect the support with the conclusion. If no one shows up to the seminars, it doesn’t matter which teaching methods are used.
This choice fills in the gap in the argument. It allows us to apply what we know about teaching methods for kids to the situation involving adult employees at Grodex."
This isn’t relevant to the argument. Memorization skills are generally not needed at Grodex.

items.stimulusText: Essayist: If Earth's population continues to grow geometrically, then in a few centuries there will be ten people for every square meter (approximately one person per square foot) of Earth's surface. Some people have claimed that this will probably not be a problem, since humans will have learned by then how to colonize other planets. This would, however, be a temporary solution at best: if the population continues to double every 30 years, and if in the year 2500 half of Earth's population emigrated to Mars, then by the year 2530 Earth would be just as crowded as it had been before the emigration.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately expresses the conclusion drawn in the essayist's argument?

options.optionContent: If Earth's population continues to grow geometrically, then in a few centuries the population density of Earth's surface will be ten people per square meter.
Due to the continuing geometric growth of Earth's population, the problem of overpopulation of Earth will probably persist.

If Earth's population continues to double every 30 years, and if at some point half of the population of Earth emigrated elsewhere, then after 30 years Earth would be just as crowded as it had been before the emigration.
The population of Earth's surface will probably continue to grow geometrically even if temporary solutions to population growth, such as colonizing other planets, are adopted.
Learning how to colonize other planets would, at best, be a temporary solution to the overcrowding of Earth.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This supports the idea that overcrowding is a serious problem; the main argument is about solutions to that problem.
This is an assumption supporting the idea that overcrowding is a serious problem.
This is used by the argument as support.
This is an assumption that the argument makes. It takes for granted that colonization won’t slow population growth, which leads to the conclusion that it is merely a partial solution.
This is the argument’s conclusion.

items.stimulusText: A recent taste test reveals that most people like low-fat chocolate ice cream as much as its full-fat counterpart. Previous tests with vanilla ice cream found that people tended to dislike low-fat versions, complaining of a harsher taste. Chemists point out that chocolate is a very complex flavor, requiring around 500 distinct chemical compounds to produce it. Hence, this complexity probably masks any difference in taste due to the lack of fat.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?

options.optionContent: Most people prefer full-fat chocolate ice cream to full-fat vanilla ice cream.
The subjects of the previous tests were not informed of the difference in fat content.
The more distinct compounds required to produce a flavor, the better people like it.
Vanilla is known to be a significantly less complex flavor than chocolate.
Most people are aware of the chemical complexities of different flavors.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This information would not strengthen the reasoning. The argument does not compare the taste of vanilla to chocolate; it compares low-fat versions of each flavor to their full-fat counterparts.

This information would not strengthen the reasoning. Knowing that the tests of vanilla were done blindly does not support the claim that chocolate’s complexity is its relevant difference from vanilla.
This choice wouldn't strengthen the reasoning. It would support the conclusion that chocolate is popular *in general*; it doesn’t explain why low-fat chocolate doesn’t taste “low-fat.”

This supplies missing information that supports the conclusion. It's only once we actually know that chocolate is a more complex flavor than vanilla that we can conclude that the complexity of the flavor is making the difference in taste.
This is not relevant; we have no reason to think that such knowledge would make a difference.

items.stimulusText: Ethicist: Robert Gillette has argued that because a thorough knowledge of genetics would enable us to cure the over 3,000 inherited disorders that affect humanity, deciphering the human genetic code will certainly benefit humanity despite its enormous cost. Gillette's argument is not persuasive, however, because he fails to consider that such knowledge might ultimately harm human beings more than it would benefit them.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately expresses the conclusion of the ethicist's argument?

options.optionContent: Gillette's argument wrongly assumes that deciphering the genetic code will lead to cures for genetic disorders.
Deciphering the genetic code might ultimately harm human beings more than benefit them.
Because of its possible negative consequences, genetic research should not be conducted.
Gillette's claim that a thorough knowledge of genetics would enable us to cure over 3,000 disorders is overstated.
Gillette's argument is unconvincing because it ignores certain possible consequences of genetic research.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The ethicist does not make this claim.
The ethicist’s conclusion is about Gillette’s argument, not about the world. Gillette’s argument is “unconvincing,” but his conclusion is not necessarily false.
The conclusion is about whether Gillette’s is convincing, not about what should or shouldn’t be done.
This isn't the conclusion. The ethicist does not question the support for Gillette’s argument, but rather criticizes the argument for failing to consider additional possibilities.
This accurately describes the argument’s conclusion and reasoning.

items.stimulusText: Many uses have been claimed for hypnosis, from combating drug addiction to overcoming common phobias. A recent experimental study helps illuminate the supposed connection between hypnosis and increased power of recall. A number of subjects listened to a long, unfamiliar piece of instrumental music. Under subsequent hypnosis, half the subjects were asked to recall salient passages from the musical piece and half were asked to describe scenes from "the film they had just viewed," despite their not having just seen a film. The study found that the subjects in the second group were equally confident and detailed in their movie recollections as the subjects in the first group were in their music recollections.
items.stemText: Which one of the following statements is most supported by the information above?

options.optionContent: Many of the claims made on behalf of hypnosis are overstated.
Hypnosis cannot significantly increase a person's power of recall.
Recalling events under hypnosis inevitably results in false memories.
What people recall under hypnosis depends to at least some extent on suggestion.
Visual memory is enhanced more by hypnosis than is auditory memory.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is too broad: the passage only gives us information about *one* claim, so we can't infer anything about *many* claims.

This inference is too extreme. The passage doesn't tell us that hypnosis *didn't* improve the power of recall for the subjects recalling the music. At best, we can say that hypnosis doesn't *always* increase a person's power of recall.

This is too extreme. Just because the hypnosis resulted in false memories for the subjects recalling the film doesn't mean that it *inevitably* leads to false memories. After all, we have no reason to believe that the subjects recalling the music exhibited false memories.

In the passage, subjects who were asked about music recalled music, while those who were asked about a film recalled a film. In other words, the memories were linked to what was suggested to them. So, the passage supports this inference.
Since the visual memories mentioned in the passage were not actually real memories, we can't infer anything about visual memory, and this doesn't follow.

items.stimulusText: Records from 1850 to 1900 show that in a certain region, babies' birth weights each year varied with the success of the previous year's crops: the more successful the crops, the higher the birth weights. This indicates that the health of a newborn depends to a large extent on the amount of food available to the mother during her pregnancy.
items.stemText: The argument proceeds by

options.optionContent: inferring from a claimed correlation between two phenomena that two other phenomena are causally connected to one another
inferring from the claim that two phenomena have fluctuated together that one of those phenomena must be the sole cause of the other
inferring from records concerning a past correlation between two phenomena that that correlation still exists
inferring from records concerning two phenomena the existence of a common cause of the phenomena and then presenting a hypothesis about that common cause
inferring the existence of one causal connection from that of another and then providing an explanation for the existence of the two causal connections

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is how the argument works: a causal connection is inferred from a correlation.
The conclusion and the support actually involve different phenomena (health vs. weight); also, the conclusion is not that any one phenomenon is the sole cause of another.
The conclusion is about a causal connection (“depends on”), not a correlation.
The argument does not say that one phenomenon is the cause of two effects.
The argument bases its conclusion on records showing a correlation, not a causal connection.

items.stimulusText:
Vincent: No scientific discipline can study something that cannot be measured, and since happiness is an entirely subjective experience, it cannot be measured.

Yolanda: Just as optometry relies on patients' reports of what they see, happiness research relies on subjects' reports of how they feel. Surely optometry is a scientific discipline.
items.stemText: Vincent's and Yolanda's statements provide the most support for concluding that they disagree over which one of the following?

options.optionContent: Happiness is an entirely subjective experience.
Optometry is a scientific discipline.
A scientific discipline can rely on subjective reports.
Happiness research is as much a scientific discipline as optometry is.
Experiences that cannot be measured are entirely subjective experiences.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Vincent says this, and Yolanda doesn’t disagree.
Vincent doesn’t express an opinion about optometry.

Vincent thinks that science has to be measurable, and happiness is subjective, so happiness can’t be studied by science. He assumes that something subjective can’t be measured, and therefore can’t be scientific. Yolanda disagrees: she names optometry as a scientific discipline that relies on subjective reports.
Yolanda doesn’t say this specifically, and Vincent doesn’t express an opinion about optometry.
Vincent and Yolanda neither agree nor disagree with this statement. Vincent assumes that all subjective experiences can’t be measured, not that experiences that can’t be measured are all subjective.

items.stimulusText: Although large cities are generally more polluted than the countryside, increasing urbanization may actually reduce the total amount of pollution generated nationwide. Residents of large cities usually rely more on mass transportation and live in smaller, more energy-efficient dwellings than do people in rural areas. Thus, a given number of people will produce less pollution if concentrated in a large city than if dispersed among many small towns.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately describes the role played in the argument by the claim that increasing urbanization may actually reduce the total amount of pollution generated nationwide?

options.optionContent: It is used to support the conclusion that people should live in large cities.
It is a statement offered to call into question the claim that large cities are generally more polluted than the countryside.
It is a statement serving merely to introduce the topic to be addressed in the argument and plays no logical role.
It is a premise offered in support of the conclusion that large cities are generally more polluted than the countryside.
It is a claim that the rest of the argument is designed to establish.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This isn't the argument's role. The argument doesn’t conclude that people should live in large cities.
This isn't the role of the argument. The argument does not dispute that cities are more polluted overall, but they contribute less to pollution per person.
The claim in question isn’t just context. It is the argument’s main conclusion.

This isn't the role the argument plays. The fact that cities are more polluted is background information that the argument does not argue against. It is mentioned to explain why the argument’s conclusion is surprising.
The claim in question is the argument’s main conclusion.

items.stimulusText: Climatologist: Over the coming century, winter temperatures are likely to increase in the Rocky Mountains due to global warming. This will cause a greater proportion of precipitation to fall as rain instead of snow. Therefore, the mountain snowpack will probably melt more rapidly and earlier in the season, leading to greater spring flooding and less storable water to meet summer demands.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the climatologist's argument?

options.optionContent: Global warming will probably cause a substantial increase in the average amount of annual precipitation in the Rocky Mountains over the coming century.

In other mountainous regions after relatively mild winters, the melting of snowpacks has led to greater spring flooding and less storable water, on average, than in those mountainous regions after colder winters.

On average, in areas of the Rocky Mountains in which winters are relatively mild, there is less storable water to meet summer demands than there is in areas of the Rocky Mountains that experience colder winters.
On average, in the regions of the world with the mildest winters, there is more spring flooding and less storable water than in regions of the world with much colder winters.
The larger a mountain snowpack is, the greater the amount of spring flooding it is likely to be responsible for producing.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Metis explanation If anything, this weakens the argument. If precipitation goes up, even if a smaller proportion falls as snow, there still might be as much or more snow to fill out the snowpack as usual.

This strengthens the argument. It says that weather patterns observed in similar conditions (a single mountainous region, relatively mild winters compared to colder winters) lead to outcomes that match the climatologist’s prediction for the Rocky Mountains.

This wouldn't have an impact on the argument. This choice compares the quantity of storable water in different areas of the Rocky Mountains, which could be related to local geographical features not connected to temperature or snowpack. The climatologist's argument is about the availability of snowpack and its implications.
This wouldn't have an impact on the argument. The climatologist predicts more flooding than in previous years, not more flooding than in warmer regions.
This would weaken the argument, by suggesting that the small snowpack will actually lead to less flooding.

items.stimulusText: Animal feed should not include genetically modified plants. A study found that laboratory rats fed genetically modified potatoes for 30 days tended to develop intestinal deformities and a weakened immune system, whereas rats fed a normal diet of foods that were not genetically modified did not develop these problems.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most weakens the argument?

options.optionContent: Potatoes are not normally a part of the diet of laboratory rats.
The rats tended to eat more of the genetically modified potatoes at the beginning of the 30 days than they did toward the end of the 30 days.
Intestinal deformities at birth are not uncommon among rats bred in laboratory conditions.
Genetically modified potatoes have the same nutritional value to rats as do potatoes that are not genetically modified.
The researchers conducting the study were unable to explain how the genetic modifications of the potatoes would have caused the intestinal deformities or a weakened immune system in the rats.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This weakens the argument by suggesting that the rat’s problems could have been reactions to eating potatoes.
This is not relevant; it neither strengthens nor weakens the argument.
This wouldn't have an impact on the argument. Knowing that they are common in general does not help us understand why they’re particularly common among rats with a certain diet.
This neither strengthens nor weakens the argument; nutritional value is not necessarily the same as “impact on health”.
The lack of an obvious explanation does not in itself weaken the finding.

items.stimulusText: Some philosophers explain visual perception by suggesting that when we visually perceive an object, a mental image of that object forms in our mind. However, this hypothesis cannot be correct, since it would require an inner self visually perceiving the newly formed mental image; this would in turn require that the inner self have a mental image of that mental image, and so on. But such an infinite regress is absurd.
items.stemText: Which one of the following arguments is most similar in its pattern of reasoning to the argument above?

options.optionContent: According to some linguists, many of the world's languages can be traced back to a common source known as Indo-European. However, Indo-European cannot be the earliest language, for if it were, then there would be no language from which it was derived. But this is highly unlikely, given the overwhelming evidence that humans spoke long before the advent of Indo-European.

The claim that any scientific theory is adequate as long as it agrees with all the empirical data cannot be correct. For there are an infinite number of theories all of which account equally well for the empirical data, and they cannot all be true at the same time.

Some historians claim that no theory is ever genuinely new; no matter how clever a theory is, there is always a precedent theory that contains its gist. But if this were true, then every theory would have a precedent theory containing its gist, and this precedent theory would also have a precedent theory, and so on, without end. Since this is clearly impossible, the historians' claim must be false.

Some engineers define a structure's foundation as that part of the structure that supports the rest of the structure. This definition is unfortunate, however, because it evokes the suggestion that the foundation itself does not have any support, which, of course, is absurd.

Some people claim that the first library was the library of Alexandria, which for many centuries contained the largest collection of books in the world. However, Alexandria's collection was itself put together from smaller collections, small libraries in themselves. It follows that the library of Alexandria was not the first in the world.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This doesn't match the pattern of reasoning. The opposing view is that many languages came from Indo-European. The speaker shifts to deny that it was the first language. There is no such shift in the stimulus.

This choice's evidence doesn't match the passage's evidence. Here, the evidence is that there are an infinite number of equally-viable theories that can't be true at the same time. However, in the passage, the evidence concerns an infinite chain of events. If you chose (B), you may have been tempted by the signal of "infinite", but a closer look shows the difference between simultaneous infinite theories and a chain of infinite events.
This matches the pattern in the stimulus. A theory is rejected on the basis of its implausible implications.

This is too vague and not strong enough to match the pattern of reasoning. The argument in the stimulus *rejects* the opposing view—it doesn’t just call it unfortunate. And it does so because the opposing view logically implies something that is absurd. Here, the opposing view merely “evokes” an absurd notion.

This doesn't match the pattern of reasoning. This argument rejects an opposing view by denying some of its factual support; it disputes the claim that the library was the first ever by pointing to its predecessors. The argument does not consist of extending an opposing line of reasoning to an absurd conclusion.

items.stimulusText: Greatly exceeding the recommended daily intake of vitamins A and D is dangerous, for they can be toxic at high levels. For some vitamin-fortified foods, each serving, as defined by the manufacturer, has 100 percent of the recommended daily intake of these vitamins. But many people overestimate what counts as a standard serving of vitamin-fortified foods such as cereal, consuming two to three times what the manufacturers define as standard servings.
items.stemText: Which one of the following is most strongly supported by the information above?

options.optionContent: Few people who consume vitamin-fortified foods are aware of the recommended daily intake of vitamins A and D.
Some people who consume vitamin-fortified foods exceed the recommended daily intake of vitamins A and D.
Some people mistakenly believe it is healthy to consume more than the recommended daily intake of vitamins A and D.
Most people who eat vitamin-fortified foods should not take any vitamin supplements.
Manufacturers are unaware that many people consume vitamin-fortified foods in amounts greater than the standard serving sizes.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: We do not know how knowledgeable people are about recommended daily intake; we just know that many many misunderstand serving sizes.
We’re told that a serving of vitamin-fortified food has 100 percent of a recommended daily intake, and many people consume two to three servings.
We do not know that anyone holds the belief; it is possible that everyone exceeding recommendations is doing so without realizing it.
We don’t know anything about vitamin supplements, so there is not enough support for this strong statement.
We do not know whether manufacturers are aware of the problem.

items.stimulusText: At the end of 1997 several nations stated that their oil reserves had not changed since the end of 1996. But oil reserves gradually drop as old oil fields are drained and rise suddenly as new oil fields are discovered. Therefore, oil reserves are unlikely to remain unchanged from one year to the next. So most of the nations stating that their oil reserves were unchanged are probably incorrect.
items.stemText: Which one of the following is an assumption the argument requires?

options.optionContent: For any nation with oil reserves, it is more likely that the nation was mistaken in its statements about changes in its oil reserves than that the nation's oil reserves remained unchanged.
It is likely that in 1997, in most of the nations that stated that their oil reserves were unchanged, old oil fields were drained or new oil fields were discovered, or both.
During the course of 1997, the oil reserves of at least one nation not only gradually dropped but also rose suddenly.
If a nation incorrectly stated at the end of 1997 that its oil reserves had not changed since the end of 1996, then during 1997 that nation drained its old oil fields and discovered new ones.
If a nation's oil reserves change from one year to the next, then that nation is obligated to report the change correctly.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The stimulus is about certain nations in a given year, so this answer is too broad in talking about "any nation" at any time. Additionally, the argument doesn't need it to be more likely that they were wrong—it needs them to be wrong.

This answer specifically limits itself to discussing the given nations in 1997, so it's very specific to the argument—a good thing for a Strengthen with Necessary Premise questions. If, in most of these nations, oil fields weren't drained and oil fields weren't discovered, then the argument falls apart—these countries very well may be correct in stating their oil reserves didn't change. The argument relies on these nations' oil reserves changing from either discovering new oil or using up old oil, so this answer is correct.
There doesn't need to be a nation that had an up-and-down year for the argument to work—just at least one nation that either went down or up.

This answer reverses the stimulus, establishing a nation being wrong as a sufficient condition, which doesn't align with reaching that determination in the conclusion. Note that if this answer stating a nation being correct about its oil reserves was a sufficient condition, then we'd have to consider it (since the contrapositive would establish the nation being incorrect as the necessary condition).

Any obligation to report oil reserves correctly is out of scope in this argument that's just about whether they did report correctly. If the conclusion added on something like, "thus violating international agreements," then we'd have to consider this answer.

items.stimulusText: If a motor is sound-insulated, then it is quiet enough to use in home appliances. If a motor is quiet enough to use in home appliances, then it can be used in institutional settings. None of the motors manufactured by EM Industries are quiet enough to use in home appliances.
items.stemText: If the statements above are true, which one of the following must be true?

options.optionContent: If a motor can be used in institutional settings, then it is sound-insulated.
None of the motors manufactured by EM Industries are sound-insulated.
At least some of the motors manufactured by EM Industries can be used in institutional settings.
If a motor is quiet enough to use in home appliances, then it is sound-insulated.
None of the motors manufactured by EM Industries can be used in institutional settings.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This confuses the necessary and sufficient conditions of the relationship we inferred: having sound-insulation means a motor is okay in institutional settings, but not the other way around.
This must be true. If any of the motors were sound-insulated, they would be quiet enough for home appliance-use, but they aren’t.
This is not necessarily true. They might all be too loud, or inappropriate for some other reason we don’t know about.
This confuses necessary and sufficient conditions: for all we know, being sound-insulated might be just one way of being quiet enough for home appliances.
This isn’t necessarily true. We know that if a motor is very quiet, it can be used in institutional settings; however, we do not know that if one is very loud that it can’t be.

items.stimulusText: Mayor: A huge protest against plans to build a chemical plant in this town was held yesterday. The protesters claim that the factory could cause health problems. But this worry can be dismissed. Most of the protesters were there only because they were paid to show up by property developers who are concerned that the factory would lower the value of nearby land that they own.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately expresses a flaw in reasoning in the mayor's argument?

options.optionContent: The argument mischaracterizes an opposing view and then attacks this mischaracterized view.
The argument attempts to persuade by inducing fear of the consequences of rejecting its conclusion.
The argument rejects a claim simply because of the motivation that some people have for making it.
The argument generalizes on the basis of a few unrepresentative cases.
The argument mistakes a claim that a result is possible for a claim that the result is inevitable.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is not a flaw in the mayor's reasoning. This choice describes a “straw man argument,” in which a speaker distorts the position of the opposing side in order to make it easier to refute. The mayor's argument, the conclusion of which is about whether the concern about health problems can be dismissed, is flawed in that it questions the motives of the people making what might be a legitimate claim.

This isn't a flaw in the mayor's reasoning. The argument does not discuss the *consequences* of believing or not believing in the potential health impacts of the factory. The mayor's argument, the conclusion of which is about whether the concern about health problems can be dismissed, is flawed in that it questions the motives of the people making what might be a legitimate claim.
This is a flaw in the argument. The protesters might not be sincere, but they might still have grounds for the claim that the factory causes health problems.

This doesn't describe a flaw in the mayor's reasoning. This choice describes a sampling error, in which an argument makes inferences about a large group based on a small and/or strange sample. There is no sampling in this argument. The mayor's argument is flawed in that it questions the motives of the people making what might be a legitimate claim.

This isn't a flaw in the mayor's argument. The argument does not overstate a certainty about a *result*; in fact, it doesn’t make any predictions at all. The mayor's argument is flawed in that it questions the motives of the people making what might be a legitimate claim.

items.stimulusText: One should not intentionally misrepresent another person's beliefs unless one's purpose in doing so is to act in the interest of that other person.
items.stemText: Which one of the following actions most clearly violates the principle stated?

options.optionContent: Ann told someone that Bruce thought the Apollo missions to the moon were elaborate hoaxes, even though she knew he did not think this; she did so merely to make him look ridiculous.
Claude told someone that Thelma believed in extraterrestrial beings, even though he knew she believed no such thing; he did so solely to keep this other person from bothering her.

In Maria's absence John had told people that Maria believed that university education should be free of charge. He knew that Maria would not want him telling people this, but he wanted these people to think highly of Maria.

Harvey told Josephine that he thought Josephine would someday be famous. Harvey did not really think that Josephine would ever be famous, but he said she would because he thought she would like him as a result.

Wanda told people that George thought Egypt is in Asia. Wanda herself knew that Egypt is in Africa, but she told people that George thought it was in Asia because she wanted people to know that George knew little about geography.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is the answer, because it meets both criteria: someone lies about someone’s beliefs, and does so *not* out of interest for the other person
Since Claude is acting in Thelma’s interest, he does not violate the principle.
John’s intentions are good, and it’s not clear that he’s misrepresenting Maria’s views.
Harvey does not violate the principle, because he only discusses his own views.
It is not clear that Wanda lied about George; if she was telling the truth, she would not have violated the principle.

items.stimulusText: Adjusted for inflation, the income earned from wool sales by a certain family of Australian sheep farmers grew substantially during the period from 1840 to 1860. This is because the price for wool sold on the international market was higher than the price paid on domestic markets and the percentage and amount of its wool that this family sold internationally increased dramatically during that period. But even though the family generated more income from selling their wool, they failed to enjoy a commensurate increase in prosperity.
items.stemText: Which one of the following would, if true, help most to resolve the apparent paradox described above?

options.optionContent: At the end of the 1800s, prices in general in Australia rose more rapidly than did the wholesale price of wool sold domestically.
The prices of wool sold to domestic markets by Australian sheep farmers decreased dramatically during the period in question.
The international and domestic prices for mutton, sheepskins, and certain other products produced by all Australian sheep farmers fell sharply during the period in question.
Competition in wool sales increased during the period in question, leaving Australian wool producers in a less favorable position than previously.
Among Australian sheep farmers, the percentage who made their living exclusively from international wool sales increased significantly during the period in question.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This does not resolve the paradox. The family’s wool income increased relative to inflation, so rising costs alone don’t explain the lack of improvement in prosperity.
This doesn’t help resolve, since the family began selling more of their wool internationally, where prices were higher, and their income from wool increased overall.
This resolves the apparent paradox. It suggests that the family may have increased their income from wool but lost income elsewhere, resulting in no added prosperity.
This does not explain why the family's prosperity did not increase—even if competition increased, so did the family’s income from wool.
This doesn’t help resolve the paradox; the number of competing wool exporters is not relevant.

items.stimulusText: Lawyer: If you take something that you have good reason to think is someone else's property, that is stealing, and stealing is wrong. However, Meyers had no good reason to think that the compost in the public garden was anyone else's property, so it was not wrong for Meyers to take it.
items.stemText: The reasoning in the lawyer's argument is flawed in that the argument

options.optionContent: confuses a factual claim with a moral judgment
takes for granted that Meyers would not have taken the compost if he had good reason to believe that it was someone else's property
takes a condition that by itself is enough to make an action wrong to also be necessary in order for the action to be wrong
fails to consider the possibility that the compost was Meyers' property
concludes that something is certainly someone else's property when there is merely good, but not conclusive, reason to think that it is someone else's property

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The lawyer bases the conclusion (a moral judgment) on a combination of factual claims and moral principles, but these are not confused.
The argument does not need this to be true, so this isn’t a flaw in the reasoning.
This is a flaw in the lawyer's reasoning. The argument says that stealing is always wrong, but that doesn’t mean that an action that isn’t stealing isn’t wrong.
This would not impact the argument, and so it isn’t a flaw in the argument.
The argument does not conclude this, so this isn’t a flaw in the argument.

items.stimulusText: From time to time there is a public outcry against predatory pricing—where a company deliberately sells its products at prices low enough to drive its competitors out of business. But this practice clearly should be acceptable, because even after its competitors go out of business, the mere threat of renewed competition will prevent the company from raising its prices to unreasonable levels.
items.stemText: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?

options.optionContent: Any company that is successful will inevitably induce competitors to enter the market.
It is unlikely that several competing companies will engage in predatory pricing simultaneously.
Only the largest and wealthiest companies can engage in predatory pricing for a sustained period of time.
It is only competition or the threat of competition that keeps companies from raising prices.
Any pricing practice that does not result in unreasonable prices should be acceptable.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The argument does not need this; the author suggests that the mere *threat* of competition would be enough to keep prices low. The argument doesn't require that competition *inevitably* result from success.
It would not hurt the argument if this were untrue.
This is not an assumption that the argument needs; the argument doesn’t concern the size and wealth of companies.
It would not be a problem for the argument if other factors helped keep prices down; in fact, this would probably help the argument slightly.
This provides the missing principle that links the support to the conclusion.

items.stimulusText: If the prosecutor wanted to charge Frank with embezzlement, then Frank would already have been indicted. But Frank has not been indicted. So clearly Frank is not an embezzler.
items.stemText: The flawed pattern of reasoning exhibited by which one of the following is most similar to that exhibited by the argument above?

options.optionContent: If Rosita knew that her 9:00 appointment would cancel, she would not come in to work until 10:00. She did not come in until 10:00. So she must have known her 9:00 appointment would cancel.
If Barry had won the lottery, he would stay home to celebrate. But Barry did not win the lottery, so he will be in to work today.
If Makoto believed that he left the oven on, he would rush home. But Makoto is still at work. So obviously he did not leave the oven on.
If Tamara believed she was getting a promotion, she would come in to work early. She did come in early. So apparently she is getting a promotion.
If Lucy believed she was going to be fired, she would not come in to work today. She is going to be fired, so clearly she will not be coming in today.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation:
This reasoning isn't similar to the argument's reasoning:

* If ***X*** (Rosita knew that her 9:00 would cancel), then ***Y*** (Rosita wouldn't come in to work until 10:00).
* ***Y***, therefore ***X***.

For this argument to be similar to the passage in its reasoning, there would need to be an element ***Z***. Additionally, the "then" clause (***Y***) would need to be denied in the second statement.

This reasoning isn't similar to the argument's reasoning:

* If ***X*** (Barry had won the lottery), then ***Y*** (Barry would stay home to celebrate).
* But ***not X***, therefore ***not Y***.

The second part of this argument doesn't match, since it denies the "if" clause instead of the "then" clause.

This matches the flaw in the stimulus:

* If ***X*** (Makoto believed that he left the oven on), then ***Y*** (Makoto would rush home).
* But ***not Y***, so ***Z*** (Makoto didn't leave the oven on).

This reasoning isn't similar to the argument's reasoning:

* If ***X*** (Tamara believed she was getting a promotion), then ***Y*** (Tamara would come in to work early).
* ***Y***, therefore ***Z***.

The second part of this argument doesn't match, since it doesn't deny the "then" clause (***Y***).

This reasoning isn't similar to the argument's reasoning:

* If ***X*** (Lucy believed she was going to be fired), then ***Y*** (Lucy would not come in to work today).
* ***Z***, therefore ***Y***.

The second part of this argument doesn't match, since it introduces the new element ***Z***as a trigger for the result ***Y***, instead of denying ***Y*** to conclude ***Z***.

items.stimulusText: Pediatrician: Swollen tonsils give rise to breathing problems during sleep, and the surgical removal of children's swollen tonsils has been shown to alleviate sleep disturbances. So removing children's tonsils before swelling even occurs will ensure that the children do not experience any breathing problems during sleep.
items.stemText: The pediatrician's argument is most vulnerable to the criticism that it

options.optionContent: relies on an inappropriate appeal to authority
relies on an assumption that is tantamount to assuming that the conclusion is true
infers from the fact that an action has a certain effect that the action is intended to produce that effect
fails to consider the possibility that there may be other medical reasons for surgically removing a child's tonsils
fails to consider the possibility that some breathing problems during sleep may be caused by something other than swollen tonsils

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This choice isn't the main weakness of the pediatrician's argument. The argument does not appeal to authority.
This criticism doesn't weaken the argument. The argument does not involve circular reasoning.
This criticism does not impact the argument. The argument does not discuss intentions.
This criticism doesn't weaken the pediatrician's argument. It is not a flaw that the argument doesn’t consider other reasons to remove kids’ tonsils; such possibilities would only help the argument.

This choice weakens the pediatrician's argument. The argument's conclusion is too strong; it assumes that swollen tonsils are the **only** cause of breathing problems during sleep. Just because tonsil surgery alleviates *one* kind of breathing problem doesn't mean it fixes *all* breathing problems.

items.stimulusText: It is unethical for government officials to use their knowledge of impending policies to financially benefit themselves if that knowledge is not available to the general public.
items.stemText: Which one of the following actions would be unethical according to the principle stated above?

options.optionContent: A company whose former manager is now an official with the Department of Natural Resources was one of several bidders for an extremely lucrative contract with the department; the names of the bidders were not disclosed to the public.
A retired high-ranking military officer now owns a company that contracts with the Department of Defense. He uses his contacts with department officials to help his company obtain contracts.

After a tax reform law was enacted, an official with the government's revenue agency obtained a 20 percent reduction in personal income tax by setting up tax shelters that were allowed by the new law.
A Finance Department official, one of the few people who knew of a plan to tax luxury cars, bought a luxury car just before the plan was announced to the public in order to avoid paying the tax.
An official with a government agency that regulates securities sold her stock in Acme just after she announced to the public that her agency was investigating Acme for improper accounting.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This scenario does not involve anyone acting on insider knowledge.
This involves a potential conflict of interest, but no improper use of government secrets.
The action was taken after the law was enacted, not before, so the action was not necessarily unethical.
This would be unethical and is the answer; the official acts on non-public knowledge for personal gain, which meets the criteria outlined in the principle.
This wouldn't be unethical. The official waited until after information about Acme went public before selling her stock, so did not benefit from insider knowledge.

content: Gerard Audesirk and Teresa Audesirk, Biology, 3rd ed. ©1993 by Macmillan Publishing Company.

sections.directions: Directions: Each question in this section is based on the reasoning presented in a brief passage. In answering the questions, you should not make assumptions that are by commonsense standards implausible, superfluous, or incompatible with the passage. For some questions, more than one of the choices could conceivably answer the question. However, you are to choose the best answer; that is, choose the response that most accurately and completely answers the question.

items.stimulusText: The quantity and type of pollution that entered the river last Thursday night suggest that the local auto repair shop is responsible. But the penalty for this type of pollution is so severe that, unless stronger evidence is discovered or the perpetrator admits responsibility, we cannot be sufficiently certain of the identity of the polluter to justify imposing the penalty.
items.stemText: Which one of the following principles, if valid, most helps to justify the reasoning in the argument?

options.optionContent: The more severe the penalty for an infraction is, the more certain one must be of the guilt of a party before being justified in imposing the penalty on that party.
Penalties for crimes should be severe enough to deter people from committing them, but not so severe as to undermine one's willingness to impose them.
The severity of the penalty imposed for an infraction should be proportional to the harm caused by that infraction.
The more severe the penalty for an offense is, the less likely it is that someone will come forward and admit responsibility for the offense.
The severity of the penalty for an offense should not be so great that one can never be sufficiently certain of guilt to justify punishment for that offense.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The passage says that the penalty can’t be justified, because the penalty is severe, and the evidence isn’t strong enough. If we accept this principle that certainty of guilt must be proportional to the severity of the penalty, then it follows that the punishment, in this case, is not justified - because it is severe, but certainty of guilt is too low.

This principle focuses on deterrence, which is not within the scope of the argument. Additionally, the arguer is unwilling to impose a penalty, whereas this principle focuses on what a penalty that *is* enforced should accomplish.

The passage doesn’t say anything about how severe the penalty *should be* - only whether the penalty should be imposed at all. So a principle about how severe a penalty should be doesn’t match the stimulus.
The reasoning in the passage concerns whether the penalty should be imposed at all, not whether someone will admit to the offense. This principle isn’t relevant to the reasoning.

This principle relates the severity of a penalty with the likelihood that the punishment will be imposed, but it doesn’t justify the reasoning in the argument. The passage concludes that the punishment should not be imposed at this time. But it doesn’t suggest that the punishment is *too severe*, or that we will *never* be certain enough to justify the punishment.

items.stimulusText: Depression is a serious problem for residents of nursing homes. However, a recent study has found that residents who developed personal bonds with pets had significantly lower rates of depression than did residents who did not develop personal bonds with pets.
items.stemText: Which one of the following statements is most strongly supported by the information above?

options.optionContent: Nursing-home residents are more subject to depression than any other individuals.
The best method for helping a nursing-home resident to overcome depression is to provide access to a pet.
High rates of depression among nursing-home residents may result at least in part from a lack of companionship.
Animal companionship is essential for psychological well-being.
Allowing free access to pets in nursing homes would eliminate problems relating to depression.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The passage concerns nursing-home residents only, but doesn’t tell us anything about other individuals, so we can’t infer this comparison.
The passage tells us only that pets *can* help nursing-home residents with depression. It doesn’t suggest that this is the *best* method of doing so.

The passage indicates that residents who developed bonds of companionship (personal bonds with pets) had lower rates of depression than those who did *not*. This indicates a link between a lack of companionship and depression, and it is therefore reasonable to infer that depression in nursing homes may be related to a lack of companionship.

The passage shows that access to animal companionship helped to lower rates of depression in nursing-home residents. It doesn’t indicate that it’s *necessary* for lowering depression rates, nor does the passage make claims about psychological well-being *overall* - in fact, it is limited in scope to nursing-home residents only. This conclusion is far too broad to follow from the passage.
The passage says that having access to a pet *decreased* rates of depression. It doesn’t claim that depression was *eliminated*, so this principle is too extreme.

items.stimulusText: Humorous television advertisements are the only effective ones. For if something is humorous it will not only attract people's attention, it will hold their attention long enough for a message to be conveyed. And, obviously, for an advertisement to be effective it must convey its message.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately describes a flaw in the argument?

options.optionContent: It takes for granted that nothing but humor can attract a person's attention and hold it long enough for a message to be conveyed.
It confuses attracting a person's attention with holding a person's attention long enough for a message to be conveyed.
It treats a necessary condition for an advertisement's being effective as if it were a sufficient condition.
It uses two senses of the term "effective" without differentiating them.
It takes for granted that an advertisement's only purpose is to convey its message.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is a flaw in the argument. The argument shows that humorous television advertisements have something that's necessary for an advertisement to be effective—that is, the ability to hold someone’s attention long enough for a message to get through. But the passage *doesn’t* show that humor is the *only* way to hold someone’s attention or convey a message. It's just *one* way to do so. So, the argument mistakenly takes for granted that humor is the *only* thing that can hold someone’s attention or convey a message.

This isn't a flaw in the argument. The argument’s support clearly states that humor can *both* attract a person’s attention *and* hold it long enough for a message to be conveyed. There’s no reason to think that the argument confuses these two concepts.

This isn't a flaw in the argument, though this choice sometimes tempts students. What's a necessary condition for an advertisement's being effective? We're told that it's necessary for an advertisement to convey its message in order to be effective. But if the argument exhibited what (C) describes, the arguer would conclude that because an advertisement conveyed its message, then the advertisement is guaranteed to be effective. That's not what happens in the passage. If you were tempted by this choice, note that the argument *does* treat a sufficient condition (humor) as if it's necessary for an ad to be effective, but it doesn't treat a necessary condition as if it's sufficient.
This isn't a flaw in the argument. There is no reason to believe that the argument uses the word “effective” in any unusual way, or that it uses the word in two different ways in the passage.

This isn't a flaw in the argument. A premise of the argument is that the ability to convey its message is a *necessary quality* for an effective advertisement. This doesn’t mean that the argument assumes that message communication is the *only purpose*.

items.stimulusText: Physician: Stories of people developing serious health problems shortly after receiving vaccinations have given rise to the question of whether vaccination is safe. But even if these stories are true, they need not be cause for concern. With millions of people being vaccinated every year, it is to be expected that some will develop health problems purely by coincidence shortly after receiving vaccinations.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, would most strengthen the physician's argument?

options.optionContent: For the most part, stories of people developing serious health problems shortly after receiving vaccinations involve vaccines that were recently introduced.
Some of the illnesses that vaccines are designed to prevent have become so rare that even if people are not vaccinated, they are unlikely to contract those illnesses.
People are no more likely, on average, to develop serious health problems shortly after receiving vaccinations than shortly before receiving vaccinations.
The health problems that some people have developed shortly after receiving vaccinations have been more serious than the health problems that the vaccines were intended to prevent.

In a few cases in which people developed serious health problems shortly after taking other medications, these problems were initially attributed to coincidence but were later determined to be due to the medications.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This detail concerning recently-introduced vaccines doesn’t tell us anything about whether or not the serious health problems are *related*to the vaccinations, and neither strengthens nor weakens the physician’s claim that the serious health problems are unrelated to the vaccinations.

The argument isn’t actually concerned with the illnesses that the vaccines are designed to prevent. Rather, it concerns whether *any* serious health problems are related to being vaccinated. Moreover, discussing what happens if people are *not* vaccinated isn’t relevant to an argument about people who *are* vaccinated.

The physician’s argument suggests that people develop serious health problems purely by coincidence, at a rate consistent with *any* group of people developing such health problems. So, if the rate of serious health problems *after* vaccination is consistent with the rate of such problems *before* vaccination, this supports the physician’s reasoning.

*How serious* the health problems are tells us nothing about whether or not the health problems are even related to the vaccinations to begin with. This comparison has no impact on the physician’s reasoning that people develop serious health problems after vaccination purely by coincidence.
This information focuses on *medications*, whereas the argument is concerned with *vaccinations.*

items.stimulusText:
Sharita: Anyone who owns a cat should have it spayed or neutered unless they are willing to take care of the cat's offspring. It is because people fail to do this that there are so many stray cats around.

Chad: Stray cats are not only a nuisance, they spread diseases and cause injuries to other cats and to humans. People feed these animals out of kindness, but doing so only exacerbates the problem unless the cats are then captured and adopted.
items.stemText: Sharita's and Chad's statements provide the most support for the claim that they agree about which one of the following?

options.optionContent: It is usually wrong to feed stray cats.
There are more stray cats than there should be.
Stray cats are a problem because of the risk they pose to humans.
Stray cats spread diseases to other cats.
It is mainly out of kindness that people feed stray cats.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: We can infer agreement from Chad’s statement that feeding stray cats “exacerbates the problem”, but Sharita says nothing about feeding stray cats, so we can’t infer whether she would agree or not.

Sharita says that there are “so many” stray cats, and that people should have cats spayed or neutered unless they are willing to take care of any offspring. From this, we can infer that she thinks that there should *not* be any more uncared-for (stray) cats. Chad says that stray cats are a nuisance and spread disease, and refers to stray cats as a “problem.” So, we can infer that Chad also agrees with this claim.
Chad claims that stray cats pose a risk to humans, so he would agree with this statement. But Sharita doesn’t say *why* it is problematic for there to be stray cats, only *how* the problem arose.
Chad claims that stray cats spread disease to other cats, so he would agree with this claim. But Sharita does not express an opinion on this.
Chad claims that people feed stray cats out of kindness, but Sharita does not express an opinion on this.

items.stimulusText: Detective: People who repeatedly commit crimes like embezzlement or bribery without being caught tend to become more confident. With each success, they believe that getting caught is less likely. However, the more crimes a person commits, the greater the chance that one of those crimes will be solved. It is therefore likely that most people who commit embezzlement or bribery will eventually be caught.
items.stemText: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the detective's argument?

options.optionContent: The majority of people who commit embezzlement or bribery do so repeatedly.
People who commit embezzlement or bribery tend to be people who feel confident.
Embezzlement and bribery are more likely to be solved than are many other types of crimes.
People who repeatedly commit embezzlement or bribery become more and more careless the longer they avoid detection.
No one who commits embezzlement or bribery is ever caught the first time.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The detective shows that people are more likely to be caught as they commit more crimes, and therefore concludes that people who commit crimes like embezzlement or bribery will eventually be caught. This assumes that people who commit such crimes will do so repeatedly. To test whether this is a necessary assumption, suppose that it is *not* true, and that people who commit embezzlement or bribery do *not* repeat their crimes. In that case, the detective’s reasoning, which is based on the repetition of crimes, makes no sense! So, this statement is a necessary assumption.

The argument concludes that people who commit embezzlement or bribery will eventually be caught, because with each crime a person commits, it becomes more likely that the crime will be solved. How confident the criminal is is not relevant to the central reasoning. So, this isn’t an assumption required by the argument.

The argument concludes that people who commit embezzlement or bribery will eventually be caught, because with each crime a person commits, it becomes more likely that the crime will be solved. The likelihood that a crime will be solved depends on how many crimes the perpetrator has committed - not necessarily on the *type* of crime it is. To test whether this is a necessary assumption, suppose that embezzlement and bribery are *no more likely* than other crimes to be solved. Would this impact the argument? Not really - it would still be the case that crimes have a greater chance of being solved, the more crimes the perpetrator has committed. Embezzlement and bribery were given in the argument only as examples.

The argument is based on the supporting claim that, the more crimes a person commits, the greater the chance that one of those crimes will be solved. The perpetrator doesn’t need to become “more and more careless” for this to be true - the crimes could be solved because detectives become more adept at interpreting evidence, or because they begin to see a pattern (that is not due to carelessness).

The argument’s conclusion is that most people who commit embezzlement or bribery will eventually be caught. So, the argument certainly doesn’t need to assume that *no one* gets caught for embezzlement or bribery the first time. After all, if we test this assumption by supposing that it is *false* - and that some people *do* get caught the first time - this *strengthens* the claim that people who commit embezzlement and bribery will eventually be caught.

items.stimulusText: If grain prices double then the average price of a loaf of bread will rise between 10 and 15 percent, whereas the price of grain-fed beef will come close to doubling.
items.stemText: Which one of the following would, if true, most contribute to an explanation of the phenomenon described above?

options.optionContent: Farmers engaged in very large-scale cattle production generally try to reduce the labor costs involved in the production and sale of beef.
The wholesale price per pound of beef is approximately ten times the wholesale price per pound of bread.
The labor and marketing costs in producing and selling bread represent most of its cost, but the cost of feeding cattle represents most of the cost of producing beef.
Only an insignificantly small proportion of the beef sold in retail markets is produced from cattle fed on grass rather than grain.
The vast majority of retail grocery outlets purchase the bread they sell from small independent bakers but purchase the meat they sell from large wholesale processing operations.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This information could help to explain why the cost of grain represents a large proportion of the cost of producing beef, but it doesn’t tell us anything about the costs involved in producing a loaf of bread, so it doesn’t explain why an increase in grain prices would have a *proportionally greater* impact on beef than on bread.
Information about the wholesale price of beef or bread doesn’t tell us why an increase in grain prices would have a *proportionally greater* impact on the cost of beef than on the cost of bread.

If true, this indicates that grain costs represent a higher proportion of the cost of producing beef than that of producing a loaf of bread. So, it makes sense that an increase in grain cost would have a proportionally greater impact on the cost of beef than on the cost of bread.

The scenario in the passage specifically concerns grain-fed beef, so information about *other* types of beef has no impact on the scenario and can’t explain why an increase in grain prices would have a proportionally greater impact on beef prices than on the price of bread.

This choice tells us nothing about why an increase in grain prices would have a proportionally greater impact on beef prices than on the price of bread, because it focuses on where grocery outlets purchase their goods and therefore doesn’t explain the scenario in the passage.

items.stimulusText:
Mark: The decongestant drug Zokaz was discontinued by its manufacturer because long-term studies revealed that it increased the risk of heart attack. Qualzan, another decongestant, works by essentially the same physiological mechanism as Zokaz. So Qualzan probably also increases the risk of heart attack.

Kathy: The decongestive effects of the two drugs do stem from the same physiological mechanism. But since they are different chemically, the two drugs probably have different side effects.
items.stemText: Which one of the following is a technique of reasoning used in Kathy's response to Mark?

options.optionContent: using a product's overall record of safety as evidence that the product is not linked to a particular health problem
attempting to discredit an argument by comparing it to another obviously flawed argument that is logically parallel
arguing against a conclusion by raising questions about the validity of scientific studies cited in support of that conclusion
attempting to undermine an argument by showing that it is incompatible with a fundamental principle of medicine
challenging an argument from analogy by focusing on a dissimilarity between the things being compared

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Kathy does not refer to Qualzan’s record of safety, so this is not the technique she uses.
Kathy does not compare Marke’s argument to any other argument, let alone an “obviously flawed” one. Rather, she points out a *difference between the drugs* that Mark is comparing.
Kathy does not question the study cited in Mark’s argument. Rather, she points out a way in which Qualzan is *different* from the drug in the study.
Kathy does not cite any fundamental principles of medicine, and doesn’t take issue with the principles underlying Mark’s argument.

Mark argues that Qualzan is likely unsafe, because it has the same physiological effect as Zokaz, which has been shown to be unsafe in the long term. Kathy counters that, while the two drugs *are* similar in this way, they are *different* in another way - their chemical makeup - and she therefore implies that Mark’s analogy may not be sound.

items.stimulusText: CEO: We have been falsely criticized for not being an environmentally responsible corporation. Environmentally responsible corporations are corporations that do all they can to pollute less. Our current production methods pollute significantly less than our old methods did, and there currently are no methods that do not produce any pollution.
items.stemText: The reasoning in the CEO's argument is flawed in that it

options.optionContent: takes for granted that production methods that do not produce pollution cannot be developed
fails to take into account the possibility that different causes can have similar effects
generalizes too hastily from the inapplicability of a specific criticism to the inapplicability of a class of criticisms
takes for granted that because the company has attempted to reduce the amount of pollution produced, they must have succeeded
ignores the possibility that there are currently production methods that would allow the corporation to produce less pollution than it does now

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The argument concerns *current* methods: an environmentally responsible corporation is one that does everything possible to pollute less, and the CEO provides information about the corporation’s current methods. Whether or not *further* methods could be developed in future is not relevant to the argument.
The CEO does not introduce any cause or effect. The argument is that the company is environmentally responsible because it has reduced pollution, but no actual causality is discussed.

The CEO’s argument deals only with countering a *specific* criticism - that the corporation is not environmentally responsible, with “environmentally responsible” defined as doing everything possible to pollute less. The CEO does not *generalize* from this criticism.

The CEO’s support states that current production methods *do* pollute significantly less than older methods. So, this isn’t something that the argument takes for granted - rather, it is an explicit premise of the argument.

The CEO concludes that the corporation *is* environmentally responsible, because it has significantly reduced pollution. But the critics define an “environmentally responsible” corporation as one that does “all they can” to pollute less. Just because the corporation has *reduced pollution*  doesn’t mean that it has done *everything possible* to reduce pollution. So, the CEO ignores the possibility that the corporation could do even more (or “all they can”) to reduce pollution.

items.stimulusText: A recent study showed that people who address problems quickly and directly are significantly less likely to have gum disease than are people who react to problems by refusing to think about them. Since stress can have a negative effect on the immune system, the study's results clearly indicate that some forms of gum disease are caused or aggravated by suppression of the immune system.
items.stemText: The argument requires the assumption that

options.optionContent: painful conditions will interfere with a person's ability to address problems quickly and directly
refusing to think about something troubling contributes to a person's level of stress
people who have highly stressful lives tend to address problems quickly and directly
people who tend to address problems quickly and directly will invariably seek dental care at the first sign of problems
the reason some people refuse to think about problems is that they find addressing problems to be stressful

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This choice ascribes one potential reason for why someone cannot address problems quickly and directly. However, it's just one *possible* reason out of many, and it doesn't *have* to be the case. Moreover, determining *why* someone can't address problems quickly doesn't help us arrive at the conclusion that immune system suppression definitely causes some types of gum disease. We need to establish the idea that refusing to think about problems is actually connected to stress to begin with.

There is a logical gap in this argument, and that is the assumed connection between “not thinking about problems” and stress. This choice addresses that gap. Here’s what we are given: 

* Refusing to think about problems → gum disease
* Stress = bad for immune system

From this support, the arguer concludes that 

* bad immune → gum disease

To test this choice (and others in required assumption questions like this one), try **negating it:** Suppose that refusing to think about something troubling does *not* contribute to a person’s level of stress. Would the conclusion hold? No - it would fall apart: Gum disease would have no connection with a bad immune system if refusing to think about problems does *not* cause stress. So, this is an assumption required by the argument.

We need to establish the idea that refusing to think about problems leads to stress. If this choice stated that people *without* stress tend to address problems quickly and directly, then we'd be on the right track. But this choice actually *weakens* the argument because it hurts the connection between *refusing* to think about problems and having stress.

Suppose that this were not true. In that case, the statement would read, “people who tend to address problems quickly and directly may not seek dental care at the first sign of problems.” This neither weakens nor strengthens the argument. Perhaps these people seek dental care soon, but not “at the first sign”? In any case, we don't establish a link between *refusing* to address problems and stress (which can affect immune systems); that link is what’s necessary to the argument.

This choice focuses on *why* people might ignore problems, but the argument concerns the *effect* of ignoring problems. Understanding why people ignore problems to begin with isn’t necessary to this argument.

items.stimulusText: A science class stored one selection of various fruits at 30 degrees Celsius, a similar selection in similar conditions at 20 degrees, and another similar selection in similar conditions at 10 degrees. Because the fruits stored at 20 degrees stayed fresh longer than those stored at 30 degrees, and those stored at 10 degrees stayed fresh longest, the class concluded that the cooler the temperature at which these varieties of fruits are stored, the longer they will stay fresh.
items.stemText: The class's reasoning is flawed in that the class

options.optionContent: generalized too readily from the fruits it tested to fruits it did not test
ignored the effects of other factors such as humidity and sunlight on the rate of spoilage
too readily extrapolated from a narrow range of temperatures to the entire range of temperatures
