An essential component of success in any scientific endeavor is good communication between the scientists involved in that endeavor and the public.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is not a supportable inference; just because excitement requires communication doesn’t mean that communication requires excitement.
This is too strong; we have no way of knowing what factor a flourishing scientific community depends on *the most*.
This is the answer. It can be inferred by combining the teacher’s statements into a transitive chain.
This is too strong. The necessary condition is that *many* kids get excited enough about science to become scientists, not that *a majority* of kids interested in science do so.
This is beyond the scope of the passage; the passage does not discuss the success of scientific endeavors, so we can’t make an inference about it.

items.stimulusText: A recent magazine article argued that most companies that do not already own videoconferencing equipment would be wasting their money if they purchased it. However, this is clearly not true. In a recent survey of businesses that have purchased such equipment, most of the respondents stated that the videoconferencing equipment was well worth its cost.
items.stemText: The reasoning in the argument is flawed in that the argument

options.optionContent: concludes that something is worth its cost merely on the grounds that many businesses have purchased it
takes a condition sufficient to justify purchasing costly equipment to be necessary in order for the cost of the purchase to be justified
rejects a position merely on the grounds that an inadequate argument has been given for it
relies on a sample that it is reasonable to suppose is unrepresentative of the group about which it draws its conclusion
confuses the cost of an item with its value to the purchaser

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This isn't a flaw in the reasoning—the support for the conclusion has to do with customer satisfaction, not the number of businesses that bought the equipment.
This isn't a flaw in the reasoning—the argument does not involve conditional statements of sufficient and necessary conditions.
This isn't a flaw in the reasoning—the argument does not just critique the magazine article’s argument; it offers evidence meant to disprove the article’s conclusion.
This is a flaw in the reasoning; the conclusion relies on a non-representative sample group.
This isn't a flaw in the reasoning—the discussion hinges on a distinction between value and cost. The argument doesn't confuse them, it argues that the value is greater than the cost.

items.stimulusText: Auditor: XYZ, a construction company, purchased 20 new trucks 3 years ago, and there is no record of any of those trucks being sold last year. Records indicate, however, that XYZ sold off all of its diesel-powered trucks last year. We can thus conclude that none of the 20 trucks purchased 3 years ago were diesel powered.
items.stemText: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the auditor's reasoning?

options.optionContent: All of the trucks that XYZ sold last year were diesel powered.
XYZ did not purchase any used trucks 3 years ago.
XYZ did not purchase any new trucks since it purchased the 20 trucks 3 years ago.
None of the 20 trucks was sold before last year.
XYZ no longer owns any trucks that it purchased more than 3 years ago.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is not a necessary assumption; what’s important is that all diesel trucks were sold, not that all trucks sold were diesel.
This is not a necessary assumption. Whether the trucks were new or used at the time of purchase is irrelevant.
This isn't a necessary assumption because it would not undermine the argument if this were false.
This assumption is required by the argument. If some of the trucks *were* sold before last year, it could be the case that some of those trucks were diesel powered.
It wouldn’t undermine the argument if this were false; it’s therefore not a necessary assumption.

items.stimulusText: Taylor: From observing close friends and relatives, it is clear to me that telepathy is indeed possible between people with close psychic ties. The amazing frequency with which a good friend or family member knows what one is thinking or feeling cannot be dismissed as mere coincidence.
items.stemText: Taylor's reasoning is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that it

options.optionContent: is based on too small a sample to yield a reliable conclusion
fails to address a highly plausible alternative explanation for all instances of the observed phenomenon
relies crucially on an illegitimate appeal to emotion
presumes, without providing justification, that one can never know what a stranger is thinking or feeling
appeals to a premise one would accept only if one already accepted the truth of the conclusion

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This isn't a flaw in the reasoning—while Taylor’s observations seem unscientific and anecdotal, the sample size was not necessarily a major weakness, given that the conclusion is just that telepathy is *possible*.
This is a weakness in the reasoning; the argument overlooks the possibility that family and friends have intuitions about each other based on experience, not telepathy.
This isn't a flaw in the reasoning—there is no emotional appeal in the argument.
This isn't a flaw in the reasoning—the argument doesn't draw a conclusion about what one can or cannot intuit about strangers.
This isn't a flaw in the reasoning—the reasoning is not circular. It doesn’t assume that telepathy exists in the course of arguing that it exists.

items.stimulusText: Prolonged exposure to sulfur fumes permanently damages one's sense of smell. In one important study, 100 workers from sulfur-emitting factories and a control group of 100 workers from other occupations were asked to identify a variety of chemically reproduced scents, including those of foods, spices, and flowers. On average, the factory workers successfully identified 10 percent of the scents compared to 50 percent for the control group.
items.stemText: Each of the following, if true, weakens the argument except:

options.optionContent: The chemicals used in the study closely but not perfectly reproduced the corresponding natural scents.
The subjects in the study were tested in the environments where they usually work.
Most members of the control group had participated in several earlier studies that involved the identification of scents.
Every sulfur-emitting factory with workers participating in the study also emits other noxious fumes.
Because of the factories' locations, the factory workers were less likely than those in the control group to have been exposed to many of the scents used in the study.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This neither strengthens nor weakens the argument, and is the answer (remember to note the word "EXCEPT" in the question!). The realism of the chemically-reproduced scents is not a factor in the argument, and note that *both* the control group and the factory workers would have been dealing with the same slightly-imperfect chemical scents. Therefore, the question remains: why were the factory workers so much worse at identifying them than the control group?
This weakens the argument by suggesting that differences in the testing conditions could have explained the different results.
This weakens the argument; it suggests that the control group may have done better principally because they had participated in similar studies before.
This weakens the argument. It suggests that it might have been some other chemical, not sulfur, that was responsible for the smelling loss (if there really was smelling loss).
This weakens the argument. It suggests that factory workers might not have been less sensitive; they could have just been familiar with fewer of the scents that were tested.

items.stimulusText:
Principle: Anyone who has more than one overdue book out on loan from the library at the same time must be fined if some of the overdue books are not children's books and that person has previously been fined for overdue books.

Application: Since three of the books that Kessler currently has out on loan from the library are overdue, Kessler must be fined.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, justifies the above application of the principle?

options.optionContent: Some of the books that Kessler currently has out on loan from the library are not children's books, and Kessler was fined last year for returning a children's book late.
One of the overdue books that Kessler currently has out on loan from the library is a novel for adults, and Kessler was fined last year for returning this book late.
None of the books that Kessler currently has out on loan from the library is a children's book and in previous years Kessler has returned various books late.
Kessler was fined by the library several times in the past for overdue books, but none of the overdue books for which Kessler was fined were children's books.
Kessler has never before been fined for overdue books, but the three overdue books that Kessler currently has out on loan from the library are months overdue.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This doesn't justify the application of the principle. It fails to establish that at least one of Kessler’s *overdue* books is not a children’s book.

This choice justifies the application of the principle. It establishes that Kessler meets the criteria of having at least one overdue book (since Kessler has *three* overdue books) that is not for children, and of having been fined in the past.

Remember that logically, "some" means "one or more".
This doesn't justify the application of the principle. It fails to establish that Kessler has been fined for overdue books before.
This doesn't justify the application of the principle. It fails to establish that Kessler currently has an overdue book for adults.
This actually hurts the argument; the principle can’t be applied unless Kessler has been fined before for overdue books.

items.stimulusText: Medical school professor: Most malpractice suits arise out of patients' perceptions that their doctors are acting negligently or carelessly. Many doctors now regard medicine as a science rather than an art, and are less compassionate as a result. Harried doctors sometimes treat patients rudely, discourage them from asking questions, or patronize them. Lawsuits could be avoided if doctors learned to listen better to patients. Unfortunately, certain economic incentives encourage doctors to treat patients rudely.
items.stemText: The medical school professor's statements, if true, most strongly support which one of the following?

options.optionContent: Economic incentives to treat patients rudely are the main cause of doctors being sued for malpractice.
The economic incentives in the health care system encourage doctors to regard medicine as a science rather than as an art.
Malpractice suits brought against doctors are, for the most part, unjustified.
The scientific outlook in medicine should be replaced by an entirely different approach to medicine.
Doctors foster, by their actions, the perception that they do not really care about their patients.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This isn't supported and is too strong; we don’t know that economic incentives are **the main** cause.
This isn't supported. Incentives and outlook are both cited as causes of poor bedside manner, but we can’t infer that the latter causes the former.
This isn't supported. The medical professor doesn't imply this; while it's suggested that many malpractice suits are avoidable, this doesn’t necessarily mean they’re not justified.
This isn't supported; the medical professor doesn’t go as far as saying that the scientific outlook should be replaced.

The medical professor's statements most strongly support this. As a result of their outlook and incentives, doctors are rude and impatient. Most malpractice suits arise out of patients' perceptions that their doctors are acting negligently or carelessly. So, doctors foster, by their actions, the perception that they do not really care about their patients.

items.stimulusText: If the concrete is poured while the ground is wet, it will not form a solid foundation. If the concrete does not form a solid foundation, it will either settle unevenly or crack. So if the concrete settles evenly, either it was poured while the ground was dry or it will crack.
items.stemText: Which one of the following arguments is most closely parallel in its reasoning to the reasoning in the argument above?

options.optionContent: The film will not be properly exposed if the camera is not working properly. If the film is not properly exposed, then the photograph will be either blurred or dark. So if the photograph is not blurred, either the camera is working properly or the photograph will be dark.

If the camera is working properly, the photograph will not be blurred. The photograph will be blurred if the film is either not properly exposed or not properly developed. So if the camera is working properly, the film will be both properly exposed and properly developed.
The photograph will either be blurred or dark if the camera is not working properly. This photograph is not blurred, so if the photograph is not dark, the camera is working properly.

If the camera is working properly, the film will be properly exposed. If either the film is properly exposed or corrections are made during the developing process, the photograph will not be dark. So if the camera is working properly, the photograph will not be dark.

The camera will work properly only if the film is properly exposed. But the film cannot be properly exposed if there is either not enough or too much light. So the camera will not work properly if there is either too much or not enough light.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This follows the argument structure of the stimulus: If *not* A (the camera is *not* working properly) then B (the film will not be properly exposed). If B, then either C (the photograph will be blurred) or D (it will be dark). So, if not C, either A (the camera *is* working properly) or D.
This argument concludes with an “and” statement instead of an “or” statement, and doesn’t match the stimulus.
This includes a premise that isn’t a conditional (“this photograph is not blurred”) and its conclusion does not include an “or” statement.
This argument’s conclusion has the form: if A, then B. But we need a conditional statement whose necessary condition is an “or” statement.
The conclusion of this argument includes an “or” statement as a sufficient condition instead of a necessary condition.

items.stimulusText: New evidence indicates that recent property development bordering a national park has not adversely affected the park's wildlife. On the contrary, a comparison of the most recent survey of the park's wildlife with one conducted just prior to the development shows that the amount of wildlife has in fact increased over the intervening decade. Moreover, the park's resources can support its current wildlife populations without strain.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?

options.optionContent: While both surveys found the same species of animals in the park, the more recent survey found greater numbers of animals belonging to each species.
The more recent survey was taken in the summer, when the diversity of wildlife in the park is at its greatest.
Migration of wildlife into the park from the adjacent developing areas has increased animal populations to levels beyond those that the resources of the park could have supported a decade ago.
The most recent techniques for surveying wildlife are better at locating difficult-to-find animals than were older techniques.
The more recent survey not only involved counting the animals found in the park but, unlike the earlier survey, also provided an inventory of the plant life found within the park.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This strengthens the argument. It adds more evidence to suggest that the park is doing well, telling us that not only is the overall wildlife population up, but the number of species has remained unchanged. This suggests that the development didn’t harm any individual species in the park, which strengthens the claim that it had no adverse effect.
This weakens the argument by suggesting that comparing the two studies could be misleading if they were conducted at different times of year.

This choice doesn’t help support the claim that the development had no negative impact. It points to a possible reason that the wildlife population has increased—animals have migrated from developing areas—but it doesn’t reinforce that the development was *harmless*.
This weakens the argument; it gives an alternate explanation for the apparent wildlife population increase.
This doesn’t strengthen the argument; it doesn’t provide evidence that plant life has gotten better or worse since the development began.

items.stimulusText: As advances in medical research and technology have improved the ability of the medical profession to diagnose and treat a wide variety of illnesses and injuries, life spans have increased and overall health has improved. Yet, over the past few decades there has been a steady and significant increase in the rate of serious infections.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to resolve the apparent discrepancy in the information above?

options.optionContent: It remains true that doctors sometimes prescribe ineffective medications due to misdiagnosis.
Life spans have increased precisely because overall health has improved.
The vast majority of serious infections are now curable, although many require hospitalization.
As a population increases in size, there is a directly proportional increase in the number of serious infections.
Modern treatments for many otherwise fatal illnesses increase the patient's susceptibility to infection.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: By drawing a similarity between now and the past, this answer makes an increasing number of infections more curious.
This answer doesn't explain the increase in infections at a time when medicine is improving.
While this answer would explain how people are surviving these infections, it doesn't explain why they're increasing to begin with.

The paradox is that the rate of serious infections is increasing. Since it's a rate, it takes into account population increases and the number of serious infections, so this answer doesn't resolve the issue. If you picked this answer, you fell for a percent (rate) to amount (number) trap!

This answer highlights a relevant difference between modern treatments and older treatments. Then, you'd die before you got an infection. Now, you live but get a serious infection. That explains how life expectancy and recovery rates are up, but so are infection rates.

sections.directions: Directions: Each set of questions in this section is based on a single passage or a pair of passages. The questions are to be answered on the basis of what is stated or implied in the passage or pair of passages. For some questions, more than one of the choices could conceivably answer the question. However, you are to choose the best answer; that is, choose the response that most accurately and completely answers the question.

items.stimulusText:
African American painter Sam Gilliam (b. 1933) is internationally recognized as one of the foremost painters associated with the Washington Color School, a group of Color Field style painters practicing in Washington, D.C. during the 1950s and 1960s. The Color Field style was an important development in abstract art that emerged after the rise of abstract expressionism. It evolved from complex and minimally representational abstractions in the 1950s to totally nonrepresentational, simplified works of bright colors in the 1960s.

Gilliam's participation in the Color Field movement was motivated in part by his reaction to the art of his African American contemporaries, much of which was strictly representational and was intended to convey explicit political statements. Gilliam found their approach to be aesthetically conservative: the message was unmistakable, he felt, and there was little room for the expression of subtlety or ambiguity or, more importantly, the exploration of new artistic territory through experimentation and innovation. For example, one of his contemporaries worked with collage, assembling disparate bits of images from popular magazines into loosely structured compositions that depicted the period's political issues—themes such as urban life, the rural South, and African American music. Though such art was quite popular with the general public, Gilliam was impatient with its straightforward, literal approach to representation. In its place he sought an artistic form that was more expressive than a painted figure or a political slogan, more evocative of the complexity of human experience in general, and of the African American experience in particular. In this he represented a view that was then rare among African American artists.

Gilliam's highly experimental paintings epitomized his refusal to conform to the public's expectation that African American artists produce explicitly political art. His early experiments included pouring paint onto stained canvases and folding canvases over onto themselves. Then around 1965 Gilliam became the first painter to introduce the idea of the unsupported canvas. Partially inspired by the sight of neighbors hanging laundry on clotheslines, Gilliam began to drape huge pieces of loose canvas along floors and fold them up and down walls, even suspending them from ceilings, giving them a third dimension and therefore a sculptural quality. These efforts demonstrate a sensitivity to the texture of daily experience, as well as the ability to generate tension by juxtaposing conceptual opposites—such as surface and depth or chaos and control—to form a cohesive whole. In this way, Gilliam helped advance the notion that the deepest, hardest-to-capture emotions and tensions of being African American could not be represented directly, but were expressed more effectively through the creation of moods that would allow these emotions and tensions to be felt by all audiences.
items.stemText: In the passage, the author is primarily concerned with

options.optionContent: describing the motivation behind and nature of an artist's work
describing the political themes that permeate an artist's work
describing the evolution of an artist's style over a period of time
demonstrating that a certain artist's views were rare among African American artists
demonstrating that a certain artist was able to transcend his technical limitations

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This choice matches the content of the passage. The first paragraph gives us some background information, the second paragraph lays out Gilliam’s artistic motivations, and the last paragraph gives examples of his work and provides an interpretation of their nature.

This choice is too narrow to be the primary purpose of the passage. There are a few implicitly political themes (like the African American experience) described in the passage and attributed to Gilliam’s work, but it doesn’t encompass the nature of or the motivations behind  Gilliam’s work, which also has artistic/aesthetic dimensions.

This is too narrow to be the author’s primary purpose, as the passage only contains **two sentences** about Gilliam’s artistic “evolution” (third paragraph)—the second and third sentences of the last paragraph.

This is too narrow to be the author’s primary purpose. The fact that Gilliam’s views were rare among African American artists is just **one component in explaining Gilliam’s motivation**, which is the passage’s main concern.

This choice doesn't describe the author's primary purpose. The passage primarily describes **why** Gilliam uses the style that he does. While the article describes how he transcends technical limitations—like experimenting with the canvas setup—the main narrative is about his artistic motivation.

items.questionType: Identifying Main Points and Primary Purposes
items.displayType: Identifying Main Points and Primary Purposes

items.stemText: Which one of the following would come closest to exemplifying the characteristics of Gilliam's work as described in the passage?

options.optionContent: a brightly colored painting carefully portraying a man dressed in work clothes and holding a shovel in his hands
a large, wrinkled canvas painted with soft, blended colors and overlaid with glued-on newspaper photographs depicting war scenes
a painted abstract caricature of a group of jazz musicians waiting to perform
a long unframed canvas painted with images of the sea and clouds and hung from a balcony to simulate the unfurling of sails
a folded and crumpled canvas with many layers of colorful dripped and splashed paint interwoven with one another

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is much more representational than Gilliam’s work as it is described.
This is somewhat representational—it sounds similar to the work of the collage artist described in the second paragraph, the kind of work Gilliam intentionally departed from.
Gilliam’s work is both *more* abstract and *more* experimental than this.
The “hung from a balcony” part of this choice sounds like something Gilliam would do with one of his canvasses, but the painting itself is far more representational than a Gilliam painting.
This choice exactly describes how Gilliam experimented with “pouring paint onto stained canvases and folding canvases over onto themselves” (third paragraph).

items.questionType: Applying the Argument to New Contexts
items.displayType: Applying the Argument to New Contexts

These efforts demonstrate a sensitivity to the texture of daily experience, as well as the ability to generate tension by juxtaposing conceptual opposites—such as surface and depth or chaos and control—to form a cohesive whole. In this way, Gilliam helped advance the notion that the deepest, hardest-to-capture emotions and tensions of being African American could not be represented directly, but were expressed more effectively through the creation of moods that would allow these emotions and tensions to be felt by all audiences.
items.stemText: The author mentions a collage artist in the second paragraph primarily to

options.optionContent: exemplify the style of art of the Washington Color School
point out the cause of the animosity between representational artists and abstract artists
establish that representational art was more popular with the general public than abstract art was
illustrate the kind of art that Gilliam was reacting against
show why Gilliam's art was primarily concerned with political issues

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The collage artist’s work doesn’t exemplify the style of art of the Washington Color School—it’s much more representational than the school’s style is.
This choice is assumes an animosity between the artistic factions, which is not mentioned in the passage.
Although it’s true that political art was more popular, that's not what this particular example serves to illustrate.

This describes why the author mentions a collage artist. The passage mentions the political collage as an example of the kind of work that Gilliam intentionally departed from. We are told that “Gilliam was **impatient** with this kind of art’s literal approach to representation. **In its place he sought an artistic form that was more expressive** than a painted figure or a political slogan, more evocative of the complexity of human experience in general, and of the African American experience in particular.”
This isn’t the point of bringing up the collage artist—Gilliam's art was his reaction **against** art that was primarily concerned with political issues, like the collage artist’s work.

items.stimulusText:
African American painter Sam Gilliam (b. 1933) is internationally recognized as one of the foremost painters associated with the Washington Color School, a group of Color Field style painters practicing in Washington, D.C. during the 1950s and 1960s. The Color Field style was an important development in abstract art that emerged after the rise of abstract expressionism. It evolved from complex and minimally representational abstractions in the 1950s to totally nonrepresentational, simplified works of bright colors in the 1960s.

Gilliam's participation in the Color Field movement was motivated in part by his reaction to the art of his African American contemporaries, much of which was strictly representational and was intended to convey explicit political statements. Gilliam found their approach to be aesthetically conservative: the message was unmistakable, he felt, and there was little room for the expression of subtlety or ambiguity or, more importantly, the exploration of new artistic territory through experimentation and innovation. For example, one of his contemporaries worked with collage, assembling disparate bits of images from popular magazines into loosely structured compositions that depicted the period's political issues—themes such as urban life, the rural South, and African American music. Though such art was quite popular with the general public, Gilliam was impatient with its straightforward, literal approach to representation. In its place he sought an artistic form that was more expressive than a painted figure or a political slogan, more evocative of the complexity of human experience in general, and of the African American experience in particular. In this he represented a view that was then rare among African American artists.

In this way, Gilliam helped advance the notion that the deepest, hardest-to-capture emotions and tensions of being African American could not be represented directly, but were expressed more effectively through the creation of moods that would allow these emotions and tensions to be felt by all audiences.
items.stemText: The passage most strongly suggests that Gilliam's attitude toward the strictly representational art of his contemporaries is which one of the following?

options.optionContent: derisive condescension
open dissatisfaction
whimsical dismissal
careful neutrality
mild approval

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Though Gilliam clearly has a negative attitude toward the representational work of his contemporaries, nothing about the passage suggests that Gilliam is derisive or condescending toward representational art, so A is incorrect.
The passage is clear about Gilliam’s dissatisfaction with the artistic movement of his contemporaries, as proven by his own artistic decisions, so the answer is (B).

Though Gilliam has a negative attitude toward the representational work of his contemporaries, “whimsy” does not describe any aspect of this attitude. He was intentionally and systematically dismissive of the status quo.

Gilliam’s attitude toward the representational work of his contemporaries is more negative than just “neutral”—he is described as being “impatient” with such work, seeking a form of art that he considered to be “more expressive” and “more evocative” of the human condition.

This choice is too positive to describe Gilliam’s attitude toward the representational work of his contemporaries—he is described as being “impatient” with such work, seeking a form of art that he considered to be “more expressive” and “more evocative” of the human condition.

options.optionContent: Draping and folding canvases gives them a sculptural quality.
Gilliam refused to satisfy the public's expectations concerning what African American art ought to address.
Gilliam's views on explicitly political art were rare among African American artists.
The Color Field style involved experimentation more than Gilliam believed the art of his African American contemporaries did.
Everyday images such as laundry hanging out to dry are most likely to give artists great inspiration.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The passage states this in the last paragraph.
This is definitely stated—it’s one of the primary claims of the passage.
The passage states this at the end of the second paragraph.

This is true to the content of the passage. Gilliam believe his contemporaries’ styles lacked experimentation, and the Color Field style is described (in the first paragraph) as being very experimental.
This claim isn’t made in the passage.

items.stemText: The passage suggests that Gilliam would be most likely to agree with which one of the following statements?

options.optionContent: Artists need not be concerned with aesthetic restrictions of any sort.
The images portrayed in paintings, whether representational or not, should be inspired by real-life images.
Artists ought to produce art that addresses the political issues of the period.
The Color Field style offers artists effective ways to express the complexity of human experience.
The public's expectations concerning what kind of art a certain group of artists produces should be a factor in that artist's work.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Gilliam most likely wouldn't agree with this. Gilliam was in fact concerned with aesthetic restrictions. The passage discusses his aesthetic considerations, like his experimentation with color and depth.
Gilliam might argue the opposite, since he produced non-representational works.
Gilliam intentionally deviated from the expressly political art of his contemporaries.

We can infer that Gilliam would agree with this. We learn in the first paragraph that Gilliam was associated with the Color Field style. Then the second paragraph tells us that Gilliam wanted his work to be “more evocative of the complexity of human experience in general” than the representational art of his contemporaries. And the last paragraph describes at length the way that the Gilliam’s art achieved this goal, capturing many nuances of emotion and experience.
We can't infer that Gilliam would agree with this. The passage tells us explicitly that Gilliam was less concerned with the public’s expectations and more concerned with his own artistic vision.

items.stimulusText:
Passage A is from a source published in 2004 and passage B is from a source published in 2007.

Passage A

Millions of people worldwide play multiplayer online games. They each pick, say, a medieval character to play, such as a warrior. Then they might band together in quests to slay magical beasts; their avatars appear as tiny characters striding across a Tolkienesque land.

The economist Edward Castronova noticed something curious about the game he played: it had its own economy, a bustling trade in virtual goods. Players generate goods as they play, often by killing creatures for their treasure and trading it. The longer they play, the wealthier they get.

Things got even more interesting when Castronova learned about the "player auctions." Players would sometimes tire of the game and decide to sell off their virtual possessions at online auction sites.

As Castronova stared at the auction listings, he recognized with a shock what he was looking at. It was a form of currency trading! Each item had a value in the virtual currency traded in the game; when it was sold on the auction site, someone was paying cold hard cash for it. That meant that the virtual currency was worth something in real currency. Moreover, since players were killing monsters or skinning animals to sell their pelts, they were, in effect, creating wealth.

Passage B

Most multiplayer online games prohibit real-world trade in virtual items, but some actually encourage it, for example, by granting participants intellectual property rights in their creations.

Although it seems intuitively the case that someone who accepts real money for the transfer of a virtual item should be taxed, what about the player who only accumulates items or virtual currency within a virtual world? Is "loot" acquired in a game taxable, as a prize or award is? And is the profit in a purely in-game trade or sale for virtual currency taxable? These are important questions, given the tax revenues at stake, and there is pressure on governments to answer them, given that the economies of some virtual worlds are comparable to those of small countries.

Most people's intuition probably would be that accumulation of assets within a game should not be taxed even though income tax applies even to noncash accessions to wealth. This article will argue that income tax law and policy support that result. Loot acquisitions in game worlds should not be treated as taxable prizes and awards, but rather should be treated like other property that requires effort to obtain, such as fish pulled from the ocean, which is taxed only upon sale. Moreover, in-game trades of virtual items should not be treated as taxable barter.

By contrast, tax doctrine and policy counsel taxation of the sale of virtual items for real currency, and, in games that are intentionally commodified, even of in-world sales for virtual currency, regardless of whether the participant cashes out. This approach would leave entertainment value untaxed without creating a tax shelter for virtual commerce.
items.stemText: Which one of the following pairs of titles would be most appropriate for passage A and passage B, respectively?

options.optionContent:
"The Economic Theories of Edward Castronova"

"Intellectual Property Rights in Virtual Worlds"

"An Economist Discovers New Economic Territory"

"Taxing Virtual Property"

"The Surprising Growth of Multiplayer Online Games"

"Virtual Reality and the Law"

"How to Make Money Playing Games"

"Closing Virtual Tax Shelters"

"A New Economic Paradigm"

"An Untapped Source of Revenue"

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The first title is too broad to fit passage A, and the second title implies a passage with a different topic than passage B. Passage A only focuses on one **discovery** of Edward Castronova, not his **theories** in general. And intellectual property rights aren’t discussed at all in passage B—taxation of virtual property is the topic.

These titles fit the content of each passage. Passage A primarily discusses Castronova discovering the economic landscape of multiplayer online games. Passage B primarily discusses how virtual property should be taxed.
Both of these titles introduce discussions not found in the passages. Passage A doesn’t mention with any “growth” in this area, and virtual **reality** is never discussed in passage B.

The first title introduces a discussion not found in passage A, and the second title is too narrow to fit passage B. Passage A doesn’t include any practical instructions for making money playing games. Passage B briefly mentions that their strategy **avoids creating** virtual tax shelters, but even this is only one part of the larger discussion of whether or not to tax virtual property.

The second title here conflicts with both passages. The first title could conceivably work for passage A, but “An Untapped Source of Revenue” doesn’t fit the content of either passage, as both passages point out that people *are* tapping into the revenue potential of multiplayer online games.

items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately expresses how the use of the phrase "skinning animals" in the final sentence of passage A relates to the use of the phrase "fish pulled from the ocean" in the second to last sentence of the third paragraph of passage B?

options.optionContent: The former refers to an activity that generates wealth, whereas the latter refers to an activity that does not generate wealth.
The former refers to an activity in an online game, whereas the latter refers to an analogous activity in the real world.
The former, unlike the latter, refers to the production of a commodity that the author of passage B thinks should be taxed.
The latter, unlike the former, refers to the production of a commodity that the author of passage B thinks should be taxed.
Both are used as examples of activities by which game players generate wealth.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Both activities can in fact generate wealth.

This choice best expresses how the phrases relate to each other. The first passage refers to “skinning animals” as something that actually takes place in games, whereas “fish pulled from the ocean” here is a real-world analogy (illustrating the effort it takes to accumulate virtual property).
This doesn't match the relationship between the references. Author A never talks about whether skinned animals should be taxed.
This doesn't describe the relationship between the references. Author B actually argues that the accumulation of virtual property, like fish pulled out of the ocean, should **not** be taxed.

This isn't how the references are related. Fishing is only used as a **real-world analogy** in Passage B—not an activity by which game players generate wealth. The passage never makes mention of players generating virtual wealth by fishing.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This choice is too negative; Author A seems to share in Castronova’s wonderment at the discovery of commerce in virtual items.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: These are likely sources for the articles. The tone of passage A is engaging and informal, like a magazine. Passage B, on the other hand, promises to make a rigorous legal case for a particular point of view.

These aren't likely sources. items.stimulusText:
Passage A is from a source published in 2004 and passage B is from a source published in 2007.

Passage A

Millions of people worldwide play multiplayer online games. They each pick, say, a medieval character to play, such as a warrior. Then they might band together in quests to slay magical beasts; their avatars appear as tiny characters striding across a Tolkienesque land.

The economist Edward Castronova noticed something curious about the game he played: it had its own economy, a bustling trade in virtual goods. Players generate goods as they play, often by killing creatures for their treasure and trading it. The longer they play, the wealthier they get.

Things got even more interesting when Castronova learned about the "player auctions." Players would sometimes tire of the game and decide to sell off their virtual possessions at online auction sites.

As Castronova stared at the auction listings, he recognized with a shock what he was looking at. It was a form of currency trading! Each item had a value in the virtual currency traded in the game; when it was sold on the auction site, someone was paying cold hard cash for it. That meant that the virtual currency was worth something in real currency. Moreover, since players were killing monsters or skinning animals to sell their pelts, they were, in effect, creating wealth.

Passage B

Most multiplayer online games prohibit real-world trade in virtual items, but some actually encourage it, for example, by granting participants intellectual property rights in their creations.

Although it seems intuitively the case that someone who accepts real money for the transfer of a virtual item should be taxed, what about the player who only accumulates items or virtual currency within a virtual world? Is "loot" acquired in a game taxable, as a prize or award is? And is the profit in a purely in-game trade or sale for virtual currency taxable? These are important questions, given the tax revenues at stake, and there is pressure on governments to answer them, given that the economies of some virtual worlds are comparable to those of small countries.

Most people's intuition probably would be that accumulation of assets within a game should not be taxed even though income tax applies even to noncash accessions to wealth. This article will argue that income tax law and policy support that result. Loot acquisitions in game worlds should not be treated as taxable prizes and awards, but rather should be treated like other property that requires effort to obtain, such as fish pulled from the ocean, which is taxed only upon sale. Moreover, in-game trades of virtual items should not be treated as taxable barter.

By contrast, tax doctrine and policy counsel taxation of the sale of virtual items for real currency, and, in games that are intentionally commodified, even of in-world sales for virtual currency, regardless of whether the participant cashes out. This approach would leave entertainment value untaxed without creating a tax shelter for virtual commerce.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately describes the relationship between the two passages?

options.optionContent: Passage A summarizes a scholar's unanticipated discovery, while passage B proposes solutions to a problem raised by the phenomenon discovered.
Passage A explains an economic theory, while passage B identifies a practical problem resulting from that theory.
Passage A reports on a subculture, while passage B discusses the difficulty of policing that subculture.
Passage A challenges the common interpretation of a phenomenon, while passage B reaffirms that interpretation.
Passage A states a set of facts, while passage B draws theoretical consequences from those facts.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This accurately sums up the relationship between the passages. Passage A focuses on **telling the story of Edward Castronova’s surprising discovery** of real-world wealth creation in online multiplayer games (“a scholar’s unanticipated discovery”). Passage B focuses on this same phenomenon—wealth-creation in online games—but through the lens of **making an argument about how tax law should be applied** to this area, since it constitutes a whole new type of “property” and as such doesn’t lend itself neatly to the tax rules (that’s the “problem raised by the phenomenon discovered”).

This doesn't describe the relationship between the passages. Passage A tells the story of an economic **discovery**, not an economic “theory.” And passage B does more than “identify” a problem resulting from that discovery—it **proposes a solution.**

This doesn't accurately describe the relationship between the passages. Passage A tells the story of an **economic discovery**—it doesn’t “report on a subculture.” And passage B proposes **a solution to a legal dilemma** pertaining to that discovery—it doesn’t discuss any “difficulty of policing” the online gaming community.

This doesn't accurately sum up the relationship between the passages. Passage A tells the story of a **recent economic discovery**—there’s no “interpretation” or “challenge” thereof. So passage B doesn’t “reaffirm” any “interpretation” from passage A, as there is none.

This doesn't describe the relationship. Passage A tells the story of an economic discovery—it doesn’t really “state a set of facts.” And passage B **proposes a solution** to the potential tax consequences that stem from this discovery. It doesn’t just draw those consequences.

items.stemText: Based on passage B, which one of the following is a characteristic of some "games that are intentionally commodified" (first sentence of the final paragraph of passage B)?

options.optionContent: The game allows selling real items for virtual currency.
The game allows players to trade avatars with other players.
Players of the game grow wealthier the longer they play.
Players of the game own intellectual property rights in their creations.
Players of the game can exchange one virtual currency for another virtual currency.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This choice flips things around—we’re looking for the sale of virtual items for real currency, not the other way around.
In-game barter is not “commodification.” Commodification refers to the sale of in-game goods in the real world.
This choice is too vague. It doesn’t define the specific parameters of commodification as they are listed.

This is a characteristic. “Intentionally commodified” refers to the game creators’ expectation that players will sell, in the real world, goods produced in the virtual world. In such a game, the players would have to own the rights to the virtual goods they produced. (If they didn’t, how would they be able to sell these goods for real money?)
This isn't a characteristic. Commodification involves exchanging virtual goods for profit in the real world (as in, for real money)–*not* exchanging one kind of *virtual* currency for another.

items.stimulusText:
In certain fields of human endeavor, such as music, chess, and some athletic activities, the performance of the best practitioners is so outstanding, so superior even to the performance of other highly experienced individuals in the field, that some people believe some notion of innate talent must be invoked to account for this highest level of performance. Certain psychologists have supported this view with data concerning the performance of prodigies and the apparent heritability of relevant traits. They have noted, for example, that most outstanding musicians are discovered by the age of six, and they have found evidence that some of the qualities necessary for exceptional athletic performance, including superior motor coordination, speed of reflexes, and hand-eye coordination, can be inborn.

Until recently, however, little systematic research was done on the topic of superior performance, and previous estimates of the heritability of traits relevant to performance were based almost exclusively on random samples of the general population rather than on studies of highly trained superior performers as compared with the general population. Recent research in different domains of excellence suggests that exceptional performance arises predominantly from acquired complex skills and physiological adaptations, rather than from innate abilities. For example, it has been found that the most accomplished athletes show a systematic advantage in reaction time or perceptual discrimination only in their particular fields of performance, not in more general laboratory tests for these factors. Similarly, superior chess players have exceptional memory for configurations of chess pieces, but only if those configurations are typical of chess games.

The vast majority of exceptional adult performers were not exceptional as children, but started instruction early and improved their performance through sustained high-level training. Only extremely rarely is outstanding performance achieved without at least ten years of intensive, deliberate practice. With such intensive training, chess players who may not have superior innate capacities can acquire skills that circumvent basic limits on such factors as memory and the ability to process information. Recent research shows that, with the clear exception of some traits such as height, a surprisingly large number of anatomical characteristics, including aerobic capacity and the percentage of muscle fibers, show specific changes that develop from extended intense training.

The evidence does not, therefore, support the claim that a notion of innate talent must be invoked in order to account for the difference between good and outstanding performance, since it suggests instead that extended intense training, together with that level of talent common to all reasonably competent performers, may suffice to account for this difference. Since sustained intense training usually depends on an appropriate level of interest and desire, and since those who eventually become superior performers more often show early signs of exceptional interest than early evidence of unusual ability, motivational factors are more likely to be effective predictors of superior performance than is innate talent.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately states the main point of the passage?

options.optionContent: Researchers have recently found that many inborn traits, including a surprising number of physical characteristics and motivational factors, can be altered through training and practice.

Recent research into the origins of superior performance gives evidence that in sports, music, and some other fields of activity, anyone can achieve exceptional levels of performance with sustained intense practice and training.

Contrary to previously accepted theories of the development of expertise, researchers have now shown that innate characteristics are irrelevant to the differences in performance among individual practitioners in various fields of activity.
Recent research involving superior performers in various fields indicates that outstanding performance may result from adaptations due to training rather than from innate factors.

Psychologists who previously attributed early childhood proficiency in such activities as music and chess to innate talent have revised their theories in light of new evidence of the effectiveness of training and practice.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This choice misreads the passage. The passage never argues that inborn traits **can be altered**—it actually argues that inborn traits **may not be responsible** for what makes people excellent at their field, as new evidence suggests that “adaptations” that come from years of intensive training and practice are responsible.

This choice is too strong. Though the passage makes a case against “innate talent” and in favor of “intense practice and training,” it never goes so far as to say that **anyone** can achieve exceptional levels of performance. In fact, the last paragraph explicitly states that it is likely the years of intense training “together with **that level of talent common to all reasonably competent performers**” that distinguishes the exceptional performers. So some level of innate talent is presumed to be necessary as well.

This choice is too strong. The passage never goes so far as to claim that innate characteristics are **irrelevant** to those differences in performance. In fact, the last paragraph tells us directly that a “level of talent common to all reasonably competent performers” is needed along with the intense training to go from just “good” to “exceptional.” In other words, the passage assumes that *some* level of innate talent distinguishes “reasonably competent performers” from poorer performers—there just may not be any innate talent difference between “reasonably competent performers” and exceptional ones.

This accurately sums up the main point of the passage. Each paragraph makes a sub-point that serves this broader goal. The first paragraph lays out the traditional view—that some notion of innate talent must account for the highest level of performance in any activity. The second paragraph asserts the passage’s thesis: new research shows that exceptional performance actually comes from acquired skills and adaptations. The third paragraph expounds upon this claim, explaining that most exceptional performers got to be exceptional via years of intense training and practice, through which they acquired these skills and adaptations. And the last paragraph concludes that the evidence supports the thesis, briefly mentioning some new implications about the predictors for superior performance.

This choice is too strong. The passage never says that the psychologists who held the “innate talent” view have now changed their theories—it only tells us that the new evidence doesn’t support the “innate talent” view. It stops short of telling us what psychologists have done (or should do) with this new evidence.

The evidence does not, therefore, support the claim that a notion of innate talent must be invoked in order to account for the difference between good and outstanding performance, since it suggests instead that extended intense training, together with that level of talent common to all reasonably competent performers, may suffice to account for this difference. Since sustained intense training usually depends on an appropriate level of interest and desire, and since those who eventually become superior performers more often show early signs of exceptional interest than early evidence of unusual ability, motivational factors are more likely to be effective predictors of superior performance than is innate talent.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately represents the primary function of the final paragraph?

options.optionContent: It makes proposals for educational reform based on the evidence cited by the author.
It demonstrates that two consequences of the findings regarding superior performance are at odds with one another.
It recapitulates the evidence against the supposed heritability of outstanding talent and advocates a particular direction to be taken in future research on the topic.
It raises and answers a possible objection to the author's view of the importance of intense training.
It draws two inferences regarding the explanatory and predictive roles of possible factors in the development of superior performance.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This paragraph doesn’t contain any proposals for reform of any kind, so (A) can’t be its primary function.
No findings are described as “at odds with each other” in this paragraph, so (B) can’t be its primary function.
This paragraph doesn’t advocate any direction to be taken in future research, so (C) can’t be its primary function.
No “objection” to the author’s view is raised at all in this paragraph, so (D) can’t be its primary function.

The last paragraph broadens the passage a bit to include the implications of the new evidence. It draws two inferences: (1) that sustained intense training usually depends on the level of interest and desire (i.e., motivational factors), and (2) that therefore, motivational factors are more likely to be effective predictors of superior performance than is innate talent.

items.stemText: Which one of the following can most reasonably be inferred from the passage?

options.optionContent: In at least some fields of human endeavor, it would be difficult, or perhaps even impossible, to ascertain whether or not a superior performer with extensive training has exceptional innate talent.
Performance at the very highest level generally requires both the highest level of innate talent and many years of intensive, deliberate practice.
Exceptional innate talent is a prerequisite to exceptional performance in some fields of human endeavor but not others.
Exceptional innate talent is probably an obstacle to the development of superior performance, since such talent results in complacency.

The importance of motivation and interest in the development of superior performance shows that in some fields the production of exceptional skill does not depend in any way on innate talents of individuals.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The passage questions the nature of innate talent. What makes the difference, the passage argues, is intense training and practice. We can infer that it would be hard to ascertain how much innate talent a superior performer who has undergone that intense regimen really has—if the training is what led to exceptionality, as the passage argues, then innate talent barely plays a role, making it nearly impossible to measure.
The passage doesn’t suppose that high innate talent is necessary—in fact, it argues that “high” innate talent isn’t a factor at all.
According to the passage, exceptional talent is **not** a prerequisite.
Exceptional talent is not described as an **obstacle**, and **complacency** isn’t mentioned in the passage.

While the first part of this choice sounds good (the author clearly believes that motivation is a critical factor), the passage never asserts that exceptional skills in any field might not **depend “in any way” on innate talent**. This is too strong. What the passage actually argues is that exceptional performance relies on "extended intense training," which is in turn reliant on being highly motivated.

items.stemText: Which one of the following does the passage say is usually necessary in order for one to keep up intense practice?

options.optionContent: desire and interest
emotional support from other people
appropriate instruction at the right age
sufficient leisure time to devote to practice
self-discipline and control

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The last paragraph clearly asserts this, telling us that “...sustained intense training usually depends on an appropriate level of interest and desire…”
Emotional support is not mentioned in the passage.
Appropriate instruction isn’t described as the key factor in maintaining intense practice.
While practice is repeatedly mentioned, the passage doesn’t specifically reference access to leisure time.
The passage might *imply* the benefits of self-discipline, but it’s not mentioned as the key factor in maintaining intense practice.

items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately describes the author's main purpose in the passage?

options.optionContent: to illustrate the ways in which a revised theoretical model can be applied to problematic cases for which previous versions of the theory offered no plausible explanation
to argue that the evidence that was previously taken to support a particular theory in fact supports an opposing theory
to show how a body of recent research provides evidence that certain views based on earlier research are not applicable to a particular class of cases
to defend the author's new interpretation of data against probable objections that might be raised against it
to explain how a set of newly formulated abstract theoretical postulations relates to a long-standing body of experimental data in a different, but related, field of inquiry

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The passage doesn’t speak of revising a theoretical model for problematic cases. What the article does suggest is that a revised **method**—studying high performers, rather than the general population—might yield different conclusions than those previously held.
The evidence the author uses to bolster the argument is **new**. The passage asserts that this new evidence provides support for a new theory.

This accurately sums up the purpose of the passage. The author begins by reviewing old research, and then refutes the old position by providing recent evidence, arguing that the old views are no longer applicable to exceptional performers (i.e., the “particular class of cases”).
The passage doesn’t seem to address any possible objections that might be raised. It puts forth a new theory without anticipating such objections.
It’s not a “different field of inquiry.” The field of inquiry is exactly the same (the pre-conditions of exceptional performance), but the theory is different.

items.stemText: The passage says that superior chess players do not have exceptional memory for which one of the following?

options.optionContent: some sequences of moves that are typical of games other than chess
some types of complex sequences without spatial components
some chess games that have not been especially challenging
some kinds of arrangements of chess pieces

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The passage doesn’t discuss superior chess players’ memory of “sequences of moves” in chess or any other game. The passage only discusses their memory of **configurations of chess pieces**.

items.stimulusText:
Physicists are often asked why the image of an object, such as a chair, appears reversed left-to-right rather than, say, top-to-bottom when viewed in a mirror. Their answer is simply that an image viewed in a mirror appears reversed about the axis around which the viewer rotates his or her field of sight in turning from the object to its reflected image. That is, the reversal in question is relative to the position and orientation of the observer when the object is viewed directly. Since we ordinarily rotate our field of sight about a vertical axis, mirror images usually appear reversed left-to-right. This is the field-of-sight explanation.

However, some physicists offer a completely different explanation of what mirrors "do," suggesting that mirrors actually reverse things front-to-back. If we place a chair in front of a mirror we can envision how its reflected image will appear by imagining another chair in the space "inside" the mirror. The resulting reflection is identical to, and directly facing, the original chair. The most notable thing about this explanation is that it is clearly based on a false premise: the chair "inside" the mirror is not real, yet the explanation treats it as though it were as real and three dimensional as the original chair.

This explanation appeals strongly to many people, however, because it is quite successful at explaining what a mirror does—to a point. It seems natural because we are accustomed to dealing with our mental constructs of objects rather than with the primary sense perceptions on which those constructs are based. In general, we can safely presume a fairly reliable equation between our perceptions and their associated mental constructs, but mirrors are an exception. They present us with sense perceptions that we naturally construe in a way that is contrary to fact. Indeed, mirrors are "designed" to make a two-dimensional surface appear to have depth. Note, for example, that mirrors are among the few objects on which we almost never focus our eyes; rather, we look into them, with our focal lengths adjusted into the imagined space.

In addition to its intuitive appeal, the front-to-back explanation is motivated in part by the traditional desire in science to separate the observer from the phenomenon. Scientists like to think that what mirrors do should be explainable without reference to what the observer does (e.g., rotating a field of sight). However, questions about the appearances of images can be properly answered only if we consider both what mirrors do and what happens when we look into mirrors. If we remove the observer from consideration, we are no longer addressing images and appearances, because an image entails an observer and a point of view.
items.stemText: The main point of the passage is that an adequate explanation of mirror images

options.optionContent: must include two particular elements
has yet to be determined
must be determined by physicists
is still subject to debate
is extremely complicated

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This accurately sums up the main point, which is that a mirror image must include the observer, and the thing observed.
This is not the main point; the article presents an explanation that has been determined.
The role of physicists is not the main point of the passage.
This is not the main point; the article presents only one correct understanding of mirror images.
Mirror images might be complicated, but that’s not the primary point of this article.

items.stemText: According to the passage, the left-to-right reversal of objects reflected in mirrors is

options.optionContent: a result of the front-to-back reversal of objects reflected in mirrors
a result of the fact that we ordinarily rotate our field of sight about a vertical axis
explained by the size and position of the object reflected in the mirror
explained by the difference between two-dimensional and three-dimensional objects
explained by the mental constructs of those who observe objects reflected in mirrors

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This conflicts with the passage—it’s the explanation that the article **refutes**, as it’s based on a false premise.
This is explicitly stated in the first paragraph: “Since we ordinarily rotate our field of sight about a vertical axis, mirror images usually appear reversed left-to-right.”
This isn’t the explanation given in the passage—in fact, size and position aren’t mentioned at all.
This isn’t the explanation given in the passage—two-dimensional objects aren’t mentioned in the article, which deals with the perception of three-dimensional objects.

This conflicts with the passage: one of the key points is that it’s **untrue** to say that mental constructs “explain” the left-to-right reversal. The mental constructs are at odds with reality because of a trick of perception.

items.stemText: According to the passage, the fact that we are accustomed to dealing with our mental constructs rather than the primary sense perceptions on which those constructs are based facilitates our ability to

options.optionContent: accept the top-to-bottom explanation of what mirrors do
understand the front-to-back explanation of what mirrors do
challenge complex explanations of common perceptual observations
reject customarily reliable equations between perceptions and their associated mental constructs
overemphasize the fact that mirrors simulate sense impressions of objects

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The top-to-bottom explanation is not mentioned in the passage.

The third paragraph states this directly. The front-to-back explanation is an example of a false mental model that we hold about mirrors. It’s an explanation that “seems natural because we are accustomed to dealing with our mental constructs of objects rather than with the primary sense perceptions on which those constructs are based.”

This is false—rather than compelling us to challenge complex explanation of our perception, our reliance on mental constructs usually works well for us, and occasionally makes us susceptible to illusions like the mirror. It rarely leads us to challenge anything.
This is the exact opposite of the correct understanding. We accept, rather than reject, customarily reliable equations of perceptions and their corresponding mental constructs.

Again, this opposed the correct view, namely that we *underemphasize* mirrors as a simulation of sense impressions, and instead actually believe the images displayed in them as real, rather than simulated.

options.optionContent: successful because it is based on incongruous facts that can be reconciled
successful because it rejects any consideration of mental constructs
successful because it involves the rotation of a field of sight about an axis
successful only to a point because it is consistent with the traditional explanations that physicists have offered
successful only to a point because it does not include what happens when we look into a mirror

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This choice isn’t supported: the author tells us that the front to back explanation **mostly fails**.
This choice isn’t supported: the author tells us that the front-to-back explanation **mostly fails**.
This choice isn’t supported: the author tells us that the front to back explanation **mostly fails**.

This choice isn’t supported. Whether the front-to-back theory is consistent with traditional explanations that physicists have offered is irrelevant and never discussed. We don’t know the author’s viewpoint on it.

The last paragraph provides support for this. The author tells us that there is a traditional motivation in science to separate the observer from the phenomenon, and that this is partially why the front-to-back theory is so appealing. But the theory falls short because we’re talking about an *observed* phenomenon—images we *see* in mirrors—so the observer must be included. In other words, if we remove the observer, “we are no longer addressing images and appearances, because an image entails an observer and a point of view.”

items.stemText: In the passage the author is primarily concerned with doing which one of the following?

options.optionContent: evaluating the experimental evidence for and against two diametrically opposed explanations of a given phenomenon
demonstrating that different explanations of the same phenomenon are based on different empirical observations
describing the difficulties that must be overcome if a satisfactory explanation of a phenomenon is to be found
showing why one explanation of a phenomenon falls short in explaining the phenomenon
relating the theoretical support for an explanation of a phenomenon to the acceptance of that explanation

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This doesn’t match the author’s primary purpose, as the author isn’t comparing these explanations. It is already decided that one of the explanations is false and the other is true—this is based not on experimental evidence but on facts about physical reality.
This misinterprets the passage—the empirical observations are identical, but the *explanations* differ.

This is true to the content of the passage, but it’s not the author’s primary concern. Rather, the author is mainly concerned with showing why the front-to-back explanation **fails**, despite its appeal.
This is the primary purpose of the passage. Specifically, the author shows why the front-to-back explanation falls short of explaining why images appear “flipped” in mirrors.

This doesn’t cover most of the passage. The acceptance of the front-to-back explanation is mentioned, but it’s not the author’s primary concern—the author mainly wants to show us why the front-to-back explanation falls short *despite* its acceptance.

items.stemText: With which one of the following statements would the author of the passage be most likely to agree?

options.optionContent: The failure of one recent explanation of what mirrors do illustrates the need for better optical equipment in future experiments with mirrors.
Explanations of what mirrors do generally fail because physicists overlook the differences between objects and reflections of objects.
One explanation of what mirrors do reveals the traditional tendency of physicists to separate a phenomenon to be explained from the observer of the phenomenon.
The degree to which human beings tend to deal directly with mental constructs rather than with primary sense perceptions depends on their training in the sciences.
Considering objects reflected in mirrors to be mental constructs interferes with an accurate understanding of how primary perceptions function.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Better optical equipment is never mentioned, so we don’t know the author’s opinion on this.

This conflicts with the implications of the passage. Physicists do NOT overlook the differences between objects and their reflections—the passage shows that they are very much interested in these differences. (Otherwise, why would they be theorizing about the differences?)

This choice is supported. The separation mentioned here is discussed in the final paragraph of the passage: “the front-to-back explanation is motivated in part by the traditional desire in science to separate the observer from the phenomenon.”
This isn’t supported—the passage doesn’t discuss training in the sciences, or how that might affect perception.

This misreads the passage. Most people don’t understand objects reflected in mirrors as mental constructs. In fact, it is the case that people think of reflected images as **real** objects—rather than perceptions—that interferes with an accurate understanding of perception.

items.stemText: The author would be most likely to agree with which one of the following statements about the field-of-sight explanation of what mirrors do?

options.optionContent: This explanation is based on the traditional desire of physicists to simplify the explanation of what mirrors do.
This explanation does not depend on the false premise that images in mirrors have three-dimensional properties.
This explanation fails to take into account the point of view and orientation of someone who is observing reflections in the mirror.
This explanation assumes that people who see something in a mirror do not understand the reality of what they see.
This explanation is unsuccessful because it involves claims about how people rotate their field of sight rather than claims about what people can imagine.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The author never describes the physicists’ motivation behind the field-of-sight explanation at all, let alone describing it as part of a desire for simplification. In the passage, the field-of-sight explanation is the de-facto “right” explanation.

This is supported by the passage. The author specifically criticizes the front-to-back explanation as depending on this false premise. The field-of-sight explanation is correct because it does not depend on this false premise.
This conflicts with the passage. As explained in the passage, the field-of-sight explanation **does** take into account the point of view of the observer.
This conflicts with the passage. The author believes that the field-of-site explanation **does** portray an accurate understanding of reality.
The author wouldn't agree with this statement because the way that people rotate their heads is *crucial* to their point of view. What people can “imagine” is irrelevant.

items.stemText: The author mentions the fact that we rarely focus our eyes on mirrors (near the end of the third paragraph) primarily in order to

options.optionContent: contrast our capacity to perceive objects with our capacity to imagine objects
emphasize that it is impossible to perceive reflected objects without using mental constructs of the objects
clarify the idea that mirrors simulate three-dimensional reality
illustrate the fact that we typically deal directly with mental constructs rather than with perceptions
emphasize the degree to which the psychological activity of the observer modifies the shape of the object being perceived

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Imagining objects is not discussed in the passage, so this isn’t the purpose of the reference. Only imagined space is mentioned.
This isn’t the purpose of the reference; the point about not focusing on mirrors is a separate topic from the discussion of mental constructs.
This is the point of the reference. In context, bringing up the fact that we don’t focus on the mirror itself, but rather “into” the mirror, shows that mirrors produce a three-dimensional simulation.

This isn't the purpose of the reference. Again, the point about not focusing on mirrors is a separate topic from the discussion of mental constructs. The mirror point refers specifically to perceptual qualities of mirrors, rather than making a broader point about cognition.

This is not why the reference was made. The point about the mirror does not deal with psychology; rather, it remarks on the illusory nature of our perception of mirrors by making a point about how, because of the mechanics of mirrors, we use them in a way that is very different from other objects.
